description:
My family and I purchase buns from here all the time. 
Recently they had a price increase 
But it's bound to happen!
This location has more options than the one in CT which is definitely a plus! 
They opened a dim sum shop 2 stores down and it's quite good. 
I'm a kid at heart so I ordered the shrimp dumpling and sui mai 
I also asked what this big potsticker wrap was and what's inside, a lady told me- chives, onion, shrimps
I got 2, and when I got home! 
There's no SHRIMP IN HERE!! (Check out photo)
Please inform your staff the correct ingredients in dim sums, because wrong information can cause a person to get sick if they were allergic to certain ingredients' 
But it was still good, my opinion, it's not as salty and flavorful but I like the texture and amora 
The Shrimp dumplings was good as well, lots of shrimps in there, the wrap is thin and soft 
The sui mai is juicey!
author: Fiona B.

description:
Not sure if all the chains has the same consistent quality control. I went in thinking it's as good as the newly opened location in outer Richmond.

The store is older, interior a bit cramped, and selections aren't as good looking. Even the cashier lady is grumpier, lol.

I got egg tarts, portugese tarts, pork floss roll and one other thing that looks like pizza on a bun. It was alright, maybe because I waited for a bit before getting to them, the buns were cold and the tart crust were chewy in a bad way. :(

And cash only.
author: YY M.

description: Have been a regular birthday cake buying location for me the cake used to be more fresh but it looks like the cake part was from storage and they just do the decoration in the back. The last cake I have I have to wait and pre-order.  If I prefer order, shouldn't it be freshly made? And it was not that good, tasted several days old. It was like a zoo with so many customers ordering birthday cakes. I am sure that is why the quality went downhill. I was disappointed and they have raised their price also. From now on I would just get the small  buns instead of birthday cakes it's not worth it.  Recently, I am not so sure about their cakes, the sponge cakes looks light and fluffy, and looks fresh with warm condensation in the bag.  It was so blend, lack of any egg flavors, full of baking soda and plain flour, and stale almost turn bad milk taste. Yuck.  Tempted to return to the store but am afraid of the rude cashier.  Luckily I was the one eating it.  If I gave to my mom she would kill me.  I tossed it instead.
author: Mar H.

description: Love this bakery. Cindy the baker will try to match any designs you bring to her. The cake is soft not too sweet and the fresh fruit decoration are unbeatable.
author: ckt p.

description: We come here all the time to purchase birthday cake.  Even ordered our special wedding cake from here.  Today I went in as usual to order birthday cake for my mother in-law.  The customer service lady just grab the cake and put it in an ugly white box.  I have to tell her twice to put happy birthday mom on it and she yelled at the bakery lady that I requested a happy birthday written on it.  This is very unacceptable.  That front lady just don't care.  We will not go back.  Worst customer services ever.   If the owner reads this, he should have some serious training on the cashier.
author: Gordon Y.

description:
I like their bread varieties, but not so much for their cakes (I'm referring to 
 their individual cakes, and not their birthday cakes).  Many times I bite into egg shells in those cakes, and that does not happen with other bakeries of the same scale.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
This place is my go to for the office birthday cake! Everyone always asks me where I get the cake from, and I say it's a little Chinese bakery a few blocks from my house. I typically get the mango cake and it's less than $30 and looks fancy af. Other mentions are the green tea cake and the mocha cake. Both are good and more of a mousse style cake. I've tried the chestnut, and the strawberry/mango and those aren't as good. So if you're looking for a quick easy place to pick up a great looking fresh fruit or mousse cake, look no further!

Aside from the cake, I've tried a number of their buns, and they are also alright. They are a little more expensive than most normal Chinese bakeries, but a little cheaper than Sheng Kee, to put that into perspective. Friends and family have enjoyed the pork puff bun, the bbq pork bun, the pineapple bun, and the hot dog bun. My personal fave is this sponge cake loaf, it looks like a rectangle and is packed in a paper bakery sleeve. It's about 5 bucks for the entire loaf, but it's like a large sponge cake, yum!
author: Eva C.

description:
3.5 Stars . I'm not overly impressed. Nothing different, nothing stood out except their green tea crepe cake which I'll explain. Located right on the corner near China town. Came across this little bakery after leaving Stinkin Rose. I was craving sweets and the pretty baked goods in the window caught my eye. Very typical Asian style bakery where you grab a tray, tongs, and get all excited piling up all the sweet goodies. Also, like most Asian bakeries I am finding that they have the most beautifully decorated pastries, but they're not as good as they look. 
Today's pastry picks;
-Black sesame toast: simple, soft, fresh. I actually liked this. Very subtle black sesame taste to this loaf of bread. 4/5 stars.
-honey comb: this was odd. Sweet interesting fast to
It. I didn't like the texture, it was kind of gelatinous, chewy 2.5/ stars
- mango mousse: this is one of those pretty desserts I was talking about. But it was bleh. The fresh mango fruit that was on top was not ripe and sweet although mangoes are currently in season. The flavor wasn't good and the cake part of it was dry. 2/5 stars
-green tea crepe cake: I saved the best for last. I was actually very surprised. This. Was. Amazing!! It's in the cooler section of the bakery, packed in a plastic container. As soon as I opened it I got a whiff of the pleasant sweet floral fragrance. It was also very pretty delicate looking dessert. Numerous thin green layers of crepe inbetween a thin spread of filling. I enjoyed eating this very much. 
Overall, I wouldn't go out of my way to come here but if I was passing by again like today I would definitely pop in to get me another one of those green tea crepe
Cakes
author: Sharon P.

description:
This place has gone downhill from the quality before.  Notice the most places when they start getting customers this is the result. 

Ordered a mango cheesecake for my birthday two says ago.  The woman over the phone confirmed it 3x placing the order.  MANGO CHEESECAKE yes.. they supposedly made it right away for me to pick up at 5pm.

I get there pick up the cake .  Goes home sing a song cut the cake into pieces pass it around ... Ew.... It's coffee cheese cake not mango.  Weirdest tasting cake ever...So how do I get my money back now.  I don't want the money.  I want the right cake .  

I'm so sad and disappointed.  Don't think I want to come here for birthday cake again
author: Juila L.

description: Large variety of freshly baked pastries. Cash Only. Friendly, efficient staff. Call ahead for a large or special order.
author: Lu-Shien T.

description:
TL;DR Pretty good Chinese bakery, not as good chinatown though

I've been here many times, mostly to get buns. Like many other bakeries now, its self serve. Grab a tray and tongs and help yourself to all the buns you can eat. 

They also have cake, but make sure to call and order ahead because if you go at the end of the day there is little to choose from, if any. 

 They recently remodeled, so the space is much larger and cleaner.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Local spot for a quick carb load. 

I come here more often than I need to for bread I don't need. It's seriously an issue, but it's nice that there is such option in the neighborhood. I love grabbing some baked goods and taking them home, eating the various goodies through the next couple of days. They make for a great quick breakfast! 

Some of my go-to freshly baked breads include: pineapple bun, cocktail bun, pork sung roll, and the newest of the bunch, durian cheese!! 

I think their winter melon cakes/wife cakes are the best! They're flakey and super chewy in the middle. 

the only thing that I dislike about this place is that the lines get long and messy, making it hard to grab pastries. They move as fast as they can but it's still slow. they redesigned recently and i wish they would have put the cashier against a wall where there are no breads... whatever. i come here and stand in line and get pushed around. it's part of the experience lol
author: Tina Y.

description: This place is a joke!  It's a "pick it yourself" bakery.  They don't have much of a variety.  Everything is buns, buns, and more buns!  They have a few cakes to choose from. Quite good and pricey!  If you are looking for service, this is not the place to go.  They don't greet you and they don't bag your purchases.  I remember handing my bag to the cashier.  She didn't take it from me.  She left the bag on the counter and stared at me like, what am I'm suppose to do with this.  I couldn't help it but laughed at her in her face.  Hey, by the way, may I have a large hazelnut, 2% milk, no foam latte to go please?  Ha, ha!
author: Jeny L.

description:
bad service! the servers always give customers a attitude. 
what's this? omg i found this inside the durian cake
author: 晓霖

description: My friend bought me this rolls... after i had it, i jus come back every weekend to buy some and bring it back to my hometown Sacramento, the butter inside taste so good... the bread is so soft... u gotta try this once...
author: Michael P.

description: The milk tea was good and tasty. The egg tart is authentic! Bread and buns are heavenly. Will visit again!
author: Olivia L.

description:
I got here on Tuesday morning around 8am . Not that crowded. Parking is easy. 
I ordered the HK milk tea and egg tart.  Both of them are super awesome. 
Will come back again to try more other items!! :)
author: Tina H.

description:
Definitely better and cheaper than Sheng Kee. There is quite a large variety of sweet and savory pastries, along with breads, tarts, and cakes. The selection seems to be more unique than those offered at other Chinese bakeries.

It's clean and well-run. I came around noon on a Friday and there was no line. Parking, as always, can be tough in this area.
author: Tim X.

description: Had to plan specifically to come here to redeem gift card. Not worth the gas. Only two locations: San Bruno Ave or Chinatown. This was lesser of two traffic evils. They do not actually bake here. Products are brought in by truck from central kitchen located elsewhere. That means all warm, moist breads and cakes are basically all trapped in dark, warm, moist climate which is perfect for growing mold. And that is what we got. Purchased assorted breads and cakes on Saturday afternoon. When took out to eat pudding cake on Sunday morning, found dots of mold. Threw away. Then took out milk bread..also covered with dots of mold. EWWW...will NEVER go back.
author: Carrie W.

description: Best place to order cakes. I had a lot of last minute orders but Cindy was able to accommodate me. Their cake is also a lot healthier than other places, just the right amount of sweetness. I have only tried their mix fruit cake but will try other flavors next time. FYI- you provide your own cake topper.
author: Leah L.

description: cindy is the best!!! the cake she made for my daughters dedication was perfect and she is really really nice.
author: Jacky G.

description:
They moved to a bigger unit and the layout is more spacious and neater compared to previous unit.

Prices are reasonable. Only short of 1 star is that i see flies in the bread area once and the staff saw it but they dont bother about it.
author: April L.

description: From now and again, I would stop at *Fancy Wheat Field* to pick up some goodies for my Auntie. They have an array assortment of baked goods. Today, I stumbled upon a "DURIAN CHEESE BUN" Yes! I said it, a "DURIAN CHEESE BUN"!!! Oh My Freakin' Jesus! It was soooooooooo good. I almost wet my pants. A must have if you love DURIAN like me.
author: Toi E.

description:
Came in to pick up a cake and asked if they could write a few words on the cake, the lady said "they are busy can't do it."
Cake was okay..
Customer service sucks! The ladies at the cashier looked really upset and annoyed with customers, they sounded unfriendly and irritated, maybe you should go work somewhere else if you hate your job so much!
author: Kandi F.

description:
Their Asian cakes taste better than Sheng Kee. The chiffon cakes are soft and fluffy like sweet clouds! The fruitcake and strawberry mouse cakes are my fave so far. Beautifully decorated as well. I always look forward to eating them.

They even give you candles and forks for your cake if you ask.
author: Tes Y.

description:
Okay, so first things first, I really like the baked goodies I got here. HOWEVER, it is a tiny little place with a not-so-thoughtful flow/floorplan, so the line gets backed up, interrupted, and muddled CONSTANTLY. 

Also it is cash only. Also, bread is baked fresh constantly so it's super soft and yummy! Also, its a popular bakery so be patient and know that you'll probably get bumped. Definitely better than Sheng Kee. Also, because of said popularity, shelves will constantly be depleted so you may have to wait for them to bring out anohter batch if your fav thing is missing.

Because it is a small place, they do not necessarily have variety. This place is more like a 3.5 star place but I like to round up.
author: Josephine T.

description: We stopped by this afternoon and had a few things including a Portuguese queijada which they call a Macao Tart. It was the closest one I've had since we left Portugal. Yum! Definitely coming back for breakfast!
author: Mysty R.

description:
Holy Buddha, I'm addicted. 

This place wasn't even on my radar as I only recently discovered it thru chance encounter at work during Christmas Eve.

I was working that evening and our co-worker brought a couple of funky-lookin' bread rolls (subsequently identified as Pork Sung Rolls) in our office. We had just finished eating our meal and I dismissed it at first. It had onions and dried pork on the sides so I was like, "Meh" at first. We put it aside and had no intention of even touching it. 

What changed my mind?

The smell eventually drew me in.

After a couple of hours of just staring at us, I said "Eff it." and I went in for a bite. The first bite got to me as it was sweet, savory and with just the right texture of fluffiness on the bread. It was like eating dessert and yet it was meaty on the same time. You get the best of both worlds and the combination of flavors and texture in my mouth felt like Heaven and Earth coming together. OK, that's a little bit overboard, but they were hella good. In fact, I immediately asked my co-worker where they get them from and I took a picture and checked it on Yelp.

I went with the Wifey a couple of days later as she used to live in this part of the neighborhood. This place has certainly changed from what I remember it back in the mid 90's. Parking is a bit of a challenge, which requires a lot of patience and you will eventually find one. Another thing which will requires lots of patience is fighting those old Asian grannies grabbing, tugging, bumping, grinding, cutting and cussing you off just to get their fill.  

If you're used to fighting them off like at the lines for the free food samples at Costco or the 38 Muni line on Geary, you should be fine. Plus the prices are inexpensive and the products are much, much, much better compared to Sheng Kee. 

I say bring on those Grannies, I'm bigger than 'em.
author: John G.

description:
Found this place by chance after some really disappointing dim sum and it turned the entire day around!!

I love egg tarts and for all my fellow egg tart lovers, you know there's two types of crusts. In my opinion, there's the flakey messy crust and the yummy crust. This place has the latter and I could not be happier!!
author: Joey R.

description:
Tiny bakery close to the 101 near south SF

Man did not know this place existed! For a tiny shop, this place sells so many different types of bakery, it's unbelievable. There is literally more baked goods than there is standing room in the place. They even have a standing shelf of mooncakes in front of the cash register--it was very tempting.

In terms of quality, the buns they sell are also pretty nice, although it's not that warm by the time I got it. Same for the tarts--you can tell it's made with quality, but was not stored in a warm area, which was a little disappointing. Still, the taste is there.

They also sell normal coffee, with very little sitting room (one table basically), which is ok. Basically, the whole place is packed with colorful cakes, high quality gift sets, mooncakes, egg tarts, and all kinds of buns. It's a real candy shop in there.

Overall, a place to grab some quick buns when you're on the go!
author: Henry L.

description:
My co-workers and friends really like this bakery. But for me It tastes OK. I give it 3 stars b/c my friend like it. I am not a fan of bakery/bread/patries at all. But Fancy Wheat Field Bakery is for sure way much better than Sheng kee. I feel really sick after eating Sheng Kee's bakery. 

Someone told me that Fancy Wheat Field Bakery has less toxic chemicals, but no where I can find or verify this information.
author: Bun -.

description:
Their egg and ham buns are always a good choice when seeking a quick bite. Service is good and the pricing of pastry items are very reasonable. I love the variety of pastries they have to offer. Also, the pastry selection is self-serve which I also liked. I'll definitely come back again for my pastry cravings.

Edit from 4/25/2017:
Pineapple Buns, Egg Tarts and other pastry items in the selection make an excellent quick grub. Especially when seeking to satisfy that craving for a pastry with a cup of morning coffee or milk tea. As always, I like the self-serve idea. Definitely a great way to choose the pastry items you want. With a the selections available, choosing the pastry items you want has never been easier. I certainly adore the idea of flexibility and variety.

Also, as an FYI:
They have moved over a few doors down. New address is 2684 San Bruno Ave.

BTW: This place is still CASH ONLY!
author: Bennett W.

description: They have amazing mango cheesecake and chestnut cake. My family have been going to this bakery for birthdays and parties for years. We always pick up the bomb ass pork song rolls as well!
author: Ada L.

description:
Of all the things we brought to our Christmas party, no one understood why we were missing dessert. Therefore, we made an emergency run to the bakery. Luckily, they were open and we got our sweet tooth cravings satisfied. We got the tiramisu cake and the family loved it. It was spongy, lightly sweetened, light, and airy... Just the way I like my asian cakes! The only thing was that the fruits were not in season so they were kind of raw and the cake didn't have much flavor, but the texture of it was amazing!

I didn't get to try anything else but everything looked so light and fluffy! Guess a trip back is due soon!
author: Stella Y.

description: Checkout cashier Asian young lady female with long black hair have no patience whatsoever after I finished paying my money for  buying their food haven't done putting away all my stuff away, get ready to leave yet, was still in line putting away my heavy stuff they get ready to assist another person right away doesn't have any patience to wait until I'm finished then proceed to the next person instead want to go to the next person right away after I pay them money it's like saying okay I got your money now get out of my face. Bunch of impatience selfish thieving payara people these day with no sense of patience and help these days just want to take your money, go, and move on to the next person/thing in life for themselves only.
author: Lorrie T.

description: was a bit disappointed. Used to be really good.  Don't know when they started to put cherry tomatoes on chocolate mouse cake, and unpeeled mango as top decorations.  Don't know how one is to cut the cake without removing the mango design with the peel. :-(
author: Carol F.

description: LOVEEEEE THEIR PORK SUNG BUS! No joke, I go out of my way to drive from the east bay to their bakery just to get them because they are just that good!! This bakery was the first bakery that I know of to make their pork sung buns in the rolled up shape. I don't know if they started the trend but I see other Chinese bakeries making their pork sung buns the same way now. I can eat so many of these in one day, it's probably a bad idea to do that but it tastes so good. I definitely recommend this bakery, you won't be let down!
author: Joanne C.

description:
Really good treats. I aimed towards the cakes and mousse. They had chocolate which is soooo good, and tiramisu, and green tea. All of which have cute presentation and the taste to compliment it all. 

This bakery does specialize mainly on Asian treats like taro tart, egg tarts, red bean bread, etc. So if that's what you're aiming for then definitely try this. 

Desserts are similar to that of shengkee bakery. If you have tried them.
author: Nikole D.

description:
OMG, this place is going down FAST in ratings! Forget that this is a neighborhood bakery and that they have delicious baked goodies to offer. This bakery is starting to skimp on its ingredients and the pastries are no longer fresh. 

I tried the honey bun and other sponge cakes and they were terrible. Let's just say they stopped putting in the full amounts of oil/butter/shortening that is required in the recipe. Instead of soft and moist cakes, these were dry and difficult to swallow. I almost choked my way through eating one of these. Please, please do not give any of the sponge cakes to children. This is a choke hazard. 

If you liked the shredded pork roll, think again. Don't even try to get these. They tend to run out fast and the kitchen fails to re-stock them in time. Also, I found out that the fresh buns gets mixed with the old ones so you might end up with one that is dried out and hard. Not appetizing nor sanitary. 

Also, beware when there are people rummaging through the trays of pastries. I caught one woman dropping one of the buns and putting it back onto the tray thinking no one will look. Hello!!! I saw you do it! 

Trays and tongs are not cleaned properly when they are placed out for customers. Wiping the trays and tongs with a dirty rag is not sanitary nor is it appetizing. 

I am very sad and disappointed in this bakery. In the beginning it seems they were trying to go beyond the typical stereotype of a Chinese bakery and create a wonderful business. Now I can see it is all about the money and cutting corners to save a little. Employees look over worked and irritated with customers. No friendly or helpful employee can be found here. Pastries and cakes are not fresh and made poorly. Not enough oil in the cakes and the taste is not like before, lack of sugar? Also, the establishment as a whole is not clean any more. You find buns and pastries on the floor, crumbs everywhere, and pastries are not kept in the proper temperature. When you buy a cake you expect the cake to be kept in a cold enough fridge and not melt on the way home.
author: Nana R.

description:
I luv this little bakery.  Discovered it when my colleague treated us for some at work Delish!!!  Now I come here once a week, to get 8 buns for my boys.  Why 8? Because it fits nicely into one of their beautiful distinctive whimsical pink n green checkered boxes.  I always buy the pork sung rolls, about $1.25.  Delish, slightly sweet mayonnaise on a fluffy sweet bread, rolled up with pork sung covering each end.  I also get the sausage buns with tomato, great for breakfast or snack, about $1.25. The cocktail buns gas a nice glaze about .55  cents. The corn and gam buns are moist and Delish.  I usually have it for breakfast when I'm in a hurry for work. Usually a box of 8 costs less than $10.  That's also includes 50 cent meter parking which buys me 15 minutes park on San Bruno.  Sometimes I get lucky and find parking in the sides streets which are free.  Overall, awesome little local bakery at reasonable prices!

Tip - cash only
author: Elaine Y.

description: I'm a regular here, really good and low price pastries, however bad cake and not really good service. The chashier is sometimes rude to me whenever I ask for separate bag for a single bun.
author: Rujii Y.

description: They really need to supply papers for the trays used to place the baked items on , I mean come on people touch them with their hands .. so unsanitary.
author: Jimmy D.

description:
When I was in China, we saw tons of little bakeries like this, full of many kinds of pastries - from sweet to savory, from snacks to meals - at very low prices. I never thought we'd find something like them in the US, let alone one with such amazing prices! It matches or beats some of the in-China Chinese bakeries which is kind of crazy. It is also almost identical to them, too, down to the type of plastic containers and the way tongs are hung up in the corner.

Many pastries are between $1-1.50, and I'd love to go back sometime and buy a lot more. We got their pizza role, which was amazing, and some almond thing . We also got their cheesecake, which was pretty typical for Chinese cheesecake - it is usually entirely baked, and it has a very mild flavor, with a hint of eggs. While I prefer American cheesecake, it's cool that this authentic option exists. 

Can't wait to go back and try more things :)
author: Chris S.

description:
I come here once in a while for some baked goods. Most of the buns on display are decent, but the section I like the best if the cold dessert section. My favorite happens to be the cheesecake. It's nice and light with a slight cheese taste. 

Some of the more warm buns are dry and not as flavorful as I'd like in a savory bun. The one in question is the ham and egg bun. The both the ham and egg was really dry and a tab bit salty. Perhaps they had a bad batch?

I'm curious to find out where most of their product comes from because time and time again, I see a big truck parking nearby and workers coming in and out of that truck to off haul some supplies and not just raw baking products, but caskets of already baked goods. Interesting... They seem to have an entire bakery behind the cash register, but most of the display items aren't nice and piping hot. I might drop by again and ask them why this is.
author: George Z.

description:
The BEST and FANCIEST Chinese Bakery in SF!

Fancy Wheat Field Bakery truly lives up to its name of being "fancy". All the baked goods look as deliciously enticing as they taste and all the credit goes to my Mom for helping me discover FWFB. Let me preface by saying that my mom is probably one of the most "budget friendliest" (aka cheapest) people known to man; i.e. she doesn't believe in spending $4-5 for a bowl of wonton mein that you can make at home. So, if she forks down more than $1 for a bao, it must be good! FWFB is a bit pricer than most Chinese bakeries but the superior quality and taste more than makes up for it. 

After my mom had bought me a FWFB's Pork Sung Bao which is one of their best sellers, I knew I had I had to pay FWFB a visit on my next bakery run. The Pork Sung Bao was ultra soft and fluffy with bits of dried shredded pork throughout that added a rich, porky savoryness. It was the BEST Pork Sung Bao I've had and I was shocked when she told me she got it from a bakery in the unassuming Portola district.

Needing a cake for a 4th of July BBQ, I came to FWFB this past Monday. Luckily, they were open otherwise I would have been screwed (Thank Gawd for Chinese businesses that open almost 365 days/year). Presentation wise, all of their cakes were simply and beautifully decorated unlike most Chinese bakeries which tend to have a 1980s cheeziness to them. I opted for the Mocha Cake ($23) which was nicely placed in a colorful sturdy box and came with complimentary cake kit (cake slicer, candles, plates and forks). 

MOCHA CAKE - LIGHT, SWEET DECADENCE!!!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AUUZV0FOBqhtYM7bUBS_KQ?select=zjU_j1y2qC5a3x34fAk36w
I grew up eating Chinese cakes, but rarely buy them because they tend to lack eye appeal, but FWFB's Mocha Cake tasted as amazingly good as it looked. The sponge cake was fluffy, airy and moist and the mocha mousse was velvety smooth with a subtle bitterness to cut through some of the richness. It was light with just the right amount of sweetness so you don't feel an ounce of guilt for face shoveling into it. Everyone at the BBQ enjoyed the cake. Even one of my friends who never eats sweets, tried a slice and said it was delicious. 

Schubert's Bakery use to be my go-to bakery for cakes, but I think I've just found my new favorite bakery. And as many Yelpers have mentioned, it's TRUE...FWFB does TRUMP Sheng Kee Bakery!

P.S.- Brownie points for the incredibly nice workers that call their female customers Leng Loi. Better than Fai Po right? MM KOI!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: I didn't like the cake. It was super dry and the fruit inside tasted extremely artificial.
author: Grace H.

description:
Coconut loaf and red bean loaf are really good.
Fluffy, quality, bread. Plenty of coconut and red bean filling inside. Generous in that respect compared to other bakeries. 
Often busy.

Recommended:
coconut loaf
red bean loaf
macau egg tart
chestnut cake cup
small cheesecake
pork sung and green onion bread

Not recommended:
honeycomb
coffee cake
author: Audrey L.

description: I'am a regular customer here for many years until recently poor customer service.  Every year I brought multiple birthday cakes and pastry here and referred lot of family and friend to them.  Today I was there to buy some pastry and the long salty white bread and have them cut it for me and turn out that the long white bread was totally messed up! The bread was all crumble up and the lady said its because the bread is still warm but when I touch it, it was not, every tho it is then they should have inform me that this would happen.  I try to explained it to them that as a customer we don't know that! They should have inform us so we have a option either have them help us pick another one that is not warm as what they said Cuz they are the expert here and with their experience.  In fact they didn't take their responsibility and told me that I can get another one but they will not cut it for me!!!
author: Bella J.

description:
As I grow older, my tastebuds have also started to become more...shall we say... corrupt. I started appreciating the finer things in life that are not necessarily good for you. Cured meats, smoked animal proteins, fattier cuts of cha siu/bbq pork, marinated innards (except liver and particular uber nasty bits), very well executed carb based dishes from certain rice plates to old world style Italian pasta to lo mein drizzled with shrimp or fish roe (karasumi, bottarga, wuyuzi/Taiwanese cured mullet roe...all the same thing). Except I am not sipping on fermented sour grapes while enjoying these rotten yummy pleasures, nor do I consume soju like a poor sod from a K-drama show. But an occasional bottle of Tsing Tao can hit the spot. And it feels like I'm up to no good. I'm just missing other vices like gambling and smoking, which I do not partake.

In an age where organic foods and eating healthy is important, people freak out at the mention of GMO beans (and thus shy away even from Soon Dubious Korean tofu stews). Organic has been the vogue word at farmers markets and causing a ruckus even in Hong Kong (where if you want to eat healthy you pay 3 times the cost of inorganic from China). 

Some say life is short, so why not eat like a pig and enjoy (and maybe pay for it later)....thus the million dollar question: what good is the quality of life if you cannot enjoy foie gras, shark fin (just kidding I'm not enamored with the stuff), abalone, toro, animal protein with insane amounts of fat, and shellfish head/innards/brain juice, or sea urchin gonads, or fatty pork with liver basked in honey sauce, or food deep fried with all sorts of old fashioned lard, without worrying about blood pressure, chloestrol HDL/LDL etc, since we are all going to croak eventually?

So with that said, one of the finer (unhealthy) things in Hong Kong local food...is a pineapple bun (bor lor bao)...not made with pineapple, but named as such. Baked bun with some sweet dough layers on top. And if it doesn't get any better than that, cut a slit either cross section from the top or on the side like a bagel, and insert a mondo sized slab of salted butter. Pair it with a solid hot HK milk tea (or coffee) and it's one of the best (and worst) things ever for your body. It's ok to skip the butter... but you're missing out. Even better if you can sit down to enjoy fresh piping hot out of the oven, and freshly brewed drink.

In SF Bay Area there are a dearth of options for being able to savor this combo.
And when that is out of reach, you just take what you can get at a HK café or a local bakery.

If geographic location and lack of competition being a factor, it is easy to understand why this bakery gets good reviews. Quick, fast, cheap, and the goods hit the spot and does what it needs to. The baked goods are slightly better packaged, more visually appealing, unlike some of the unrefined fugly you see in parts of Chinatown. It is a favorite for the locals, some of which are Cantonese speakers, but the majority appear to be Toishanese from Southern China (after all this is their territory!). Looking at the words on the wall, it's shorthand Chinese...so the only Hong Kong "style" is the approach, but it ends there.

The baked goods are a bit too sweet for my liking.

Egg tart (dan taat) - cookie crust rendition. Unfortunately even at 8 am, this must be either yesterday's batch...it was as cold as the morning air. Not terribly exciting, but definitely better than something like Hong Kong Bakery in downtown Mountain View, or Sheng Kee

Macau style Portugese egg tart (po taat) - these are at the bottom shelf from the regular egg tarts. Don't bother...these are the worst po taat I've ever had. What is the opposite of "fancy"? Head to Sogo Bakery in Burlingame, and if you are lucky to encounter ones fresh out of the oven, they are indeed the Lady Gaga of Egg Tarts.

Pork Sung Bun - Looked like a pretty elegant non layered croissant. The inside was sweet...like a coconut paste, and they mixed in the "pork floss" (yok sung or rou song in Mandarin). This was more palatable than the egg tarts, but still not quite my bag. Maybe the ham and pork sung hairy bun would be better...but this unfortunately did not blow me away like it did to my other Yelp friends. 

Hot milk tea - Eeek....again too sweet. But being able to get a hot coffee or hot milk tea here in the AM is already not bad (not like you can find it elsewhere nearby I think). At least it did not give me the runs like some of the other bakeries in the Peninsula that do this drink. It's not HK café like goodness (like Tak Kee Lee). Maybe a Yin Yang remix would be better (half coffee half hot milk tea)? Don't know.
author: Ken K.

description: Cash only. Small place. Busy all the time. But worth it. Breads are good. Quick question. Are they open at thanksgiving
author: Amanda F.

description:
It was Christmas and normally we have a table full of desserts, but this year... nada! How does one end a meal without dessert?!?!

We made a trip over here to grab a cake and we picked the Tiramisu. It was ~$20 for a 8" cake, which I think is pretty normal for an Asian Bakery cake. It was fully decorated on top with lots of plastic decorations (some decorations looked like it was from Thanksgiving), but we were here for the cake, so we didn't care that much.

They wrapped it in a pretty cool box and we told it home and immediately started serving. Considering the Tiramisu was Asian made, it was really good! Had the chocolate, cream, and coffee flavor and it wasn't too sweet which all the older members of the family always appreciate. I enjoyed it and had too slices (though if you put any cake in front of me, don't expect too much leftovers hahaha).

Overall, this cake was good so it's definitely on our list of Asian Bakeries for cake buying. I'll be back to try the other pastries as well.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Originally ended up here because we were searching for pork buns on yelp and this was the closest spot. When I got there, every Asian was putting this one strange looking item onto their trays. Had no idea what it was but we decided to get one to see what it's all about. We got home, tried it, and now we only come here for that: pork sung rolls. I've tried it at other Chinese bakeries since then but this place makes the best one - just the right amount of sweet and savory.

It's all self serve and the customer service is not that helpful, but I come back for the pork sung rolls. 

Cash only.
author: Zell C.

description:
Tiny little bakery located across the street from where I used to work. There's no tables inside and barely any standing room. I used to go here sometimes to grab buns for breakfast or a dessert to cheer somebody up. Really friendly and have really nice boxes for the cakes as well. Everything I've tried there so far has been good, so I don't think you can go wrong.

Cash only, so come prepared!
author: Kitty K.

description:
Great buns. Addicted to their pork sun roll with ham and green onions. 

Love their cakes! They have the cutest cake boxes I've ever seen PLUS they give you a set of plates, knife, forks, even candles! for free.

Prices are great.
author: Erica L.

description:
It's hard to believe that there's any "Fancy" anything in Portola, but believe it or not this bakery is mighty fancy.

If you just look at the breads/desserts that they have, you'd think it costs double than what they charge. All the breads look nice with buttery finish, aluminium foil base, and packaged in little plastic bags. And because people can grab their own bread, service is fast and you don't need to defend your line against old chinese ladies.
author: Novalina N.

description: Stopped by here, because it was super busy and wanted to see what the noise was about. I got a bbq pork bun and omg was it so damn good. Wish I would've gotten two LOL can't wait to go back
author: Katherine R.

description: Cute a little Asian bakery in Portola, but was pretty disappointed with their breads. Limited selection and the sweet breads lacked butter. I got the custard, red bean, and pineapple bun - all fairly mediocre. The custard was particularly underwhelming as it resembled more of the coconut cocktail bun rather than the creamy custard-filled center like I'm use to. Apparently their meat bun is really good. I'm not the biggest fan of savory buns but will give this a try next time!
author: Betty W.

description: Stopped here for some egg tarts.. Bakery is super clean, fast service, and very inexpensive! Everything was delicious and the best part of this experience is you grab your own stuff and than pay which I love. I can take my time and grab what I want, bring them the tray when your done and they package it up for you!
author: Kimberly D.

description: Love that this place is close to my house. The pineapple bun and pork bun are my go-to buys here.
author: Darwin D.

description: Both Chinatown and San Bruno Ave locations have dirty carpets typical of Chinese owned places, the store on Stockton and Vallejo St in Chinatown has stinky run down bare red carpeting.  I used to like getting coffee and hk milktea here but the smell is unacceptable.  The goods aren't as good as when they first opened.
author: Ken K.

description:
I'd give this 5 stars but I'll explain later.

I'm in LOVE with all of the pastries they have in the front window. They're always fresh, chewy, and if you come at the right time, they're still hot!

Very popular spot. The crust of their dan tat (egg tart) is almost like a short-bread, unless you get the "portuguese" style one, which is more often when I see at other Chinese bakeries (it's the flakey one with the browned top). I like the first one better obviously ^_^




The reason for not giving 5 stars:
I didn't like any of the things I bought that were in the "pre-packaged" pastry section. Their honeycomb cakes were mediocre, the egg-yolk balls are also very average. And I'm afraid to try the beautifully decorated desserts at the front because the roll cakes and white cakes were really bad.


TLDR: Get the stuff up front. It's fresher and always good.
author: Ellie M.

description: My first green tea mousse cake for my daughter's birthday, worse cake I ever had, the first layer is horrify green color jello (  my daughter said it taste like toothpaste, it was mint actually), next layer was very thin green tea mousse ( can't taste like green tea at all). Center is cake and more yellow jello around it (? what ?) when I first pick up I asked "where is my cake?" The bottom suppose to be all CAKE!  And also it was way too sweet! I used to have their mango mousse cake or regular cake and they are good!  No more green tea next time"
author: Judy S.

description:
SO FAR ! BUT SO YUMMMMYYYYYYYYY!! love it !
only thing i don't love is how there isn't parking outside :[
author: Jenny N.

description: Pastries always fresh.  My husband and I always make an effort to go to this particular bakery since it's self service which allows you to get the pastries you want without having to talk to someone especially if you don't know the language.
author: Judy H.

description:
I really enjoy this Bakery. The location is on a busy street on San Bruno Ave, and parking is sometimes hard to find, but not impossible. Similar to a ShengKee, but their cakes are bomb! I've tried most of the larger cakes for parties, like their greentea mousse cake (which is my favorite), and their regular chinese sponge cake is really good as well because it's not too sweet and has fresh fruit inside. I like chinese cakes because their cream/icing is not buttercream icing and sometimes, after a large meal you just want a light airy cake. 

I would say, if you have a party, just call in and reserve a cake. For my grandma's birthday, I tried walking in and picking up a cake, and at least 7 of them were already reserved so I had to settle for something that I didn't originally want to buy. When you buy a cake, they put it in a gorgeous colorful box, that comes with plates, plastic knives, mini forks, as well as 2 candles. Perfect for a party! 

Tons of selections of buns, tarts, breads, as well as larger cakes and mini mousses and cake slices.
author: Carmen C.

description:
Went here before a long time ago for afternoon snacks, the orientation of the store is just like Sheng Ky, you grab a tray and place what you want. Your typical asian Bakery, simple and to the point. They have your typical array of hot dog buns, corn and cheese, shredded pork, etc. 

Came back today to pick up their green tea mousse cake that all the yelpers wrote about, and they were right. DELISH! I called to order this morning and the lady on the phone was kind even though she had a hard time understanding me. I came to pick it up today and it was ready to go. It was very tea-y, fresh, and light without being overly sweet. My mom loved her birthday cake and at 25$ a pop this 8 inch cake was a steal. Will definitely come back again soon to try their other cakes. They have a huge display of cakes! If you're looking for a sweet treat without overloading on the sugar, this is the place to be!

They even give you a cute little bag full of plates, forks, candles and a cake knife. Nice perk!
author: Thuy M.

description: I gave the 2 starts for the quality of the product and the price range. The ladies that work there always focus on their own conversation but not the customer needs. No greeting, no ask for preference for bagging or boxing etc. For whatever reasons that lead them to have such performance, something should be done about it.
author: Lianna D.

description:
Truly a hidden gem in San Francisco's Portola district. Excellent cakes and pastries at an affordable price! I absolutely love this place! 

I have tried their tiramisu mousse cake, mocha mousse cake, and green tea mousse cake. All are as delicious as they are aesthetic; far better than Sheng Kee. The tiramisu and mocha cakes are fairly as expected, but the green tea mousse cake was a very pleasant surprise! Moreover, the cakes were only $23 each, which is very reasonable considering the quality. 

WILL DEFINITELY GO BACK!
author: Willk W.

description:
Finding a cake for your wedding can be so difficult when your on a budget! For about 250 guests, wedding cakes can cost over $1000, which i think is just way too expensive!! Believe me, my husband and I sampled so many cakes (and he doesn't even really like cake!). But whenever bakeries quoted us, it cost almost $1000 bucks, which is just ridiculous for cake! Although my husband doesn't really like cake, he said he does like one type of cake -- mixed fruit cake with whipped cream from Chinese bakeries. He mentioned Fancy Wheat to me, and that he tried stuff from there before. So I checked them out on Yelp and they got great reviews--mostly about their buns and desserts, but they actually do wedding cakes too! 

When we went to the bakery, there was a huge language barrier since hardly any of the workers speak any English. But I spoke with Cindy, who does speak some English, and she showed us their wedding cake pictures. They don't give out samples of their cakes--you just buy the small cakes they have already made and tell them which one you want for your cake. We ended up ordering a 3 tier cake plus a sheet cake for 250 guests and for HALF the price we would have originally paid if we went with those other fancy bakeries!! Our bottom layer was tiramisu, middle layer was mixed fruit, and the top layer was strawberry mango mousse. All were delicious, especially the tiramisu!!! Our sheet cake was half tiramisu and mixed fruit. We paid the deposit in cash, and all we had to do was bring in the ribbon with the remaining deposit before the wedding. 

On my next visit, I brought the ribbon and remaining deposit, and met with the baker, Wesley, who was the guy who would be making our cake. He spoke perfect English, so i felt more comfortable knowing that there would be no confusion on how the cake should be made. He was very nice and gave me his email to contact him for any questions. 

Wedding day: The cake arrived on time and it was exactly how I wanted--beautiful, simple, and delicious. All of our guests loved it!! Some said it was the best tiramisu they've ever had! We even had some cake leftover, so we brought it to our family party the next day. 

Fancy Wheat Field Bakery is the best Chinese bakery around! Their cakes are delicious and affordable. Their pork buns are also to die for and super cheap (i ordered some each time i went there)!! I'll definitely go back for more!
author: Jenn Z.

description: Luv this bakery, never been i think its in SF someone brought in some goodies and i ate more than i s j ould have but it was realy good, i wont make a special trip to buy some but if i ever go i will stop in.
author: Chrissy V.

description:
This review is on behalf of my 5 year old son!  

He looooooooooves this place for their Hot Dog Buns and the Ham and Egg Buns.  If this child can have his way EVERY morning before preschool, he would choose to stop off at Fancy Wheat Field's!!!  For obvious reasons, we do not have hot dog buns every morning! ;)

However, we do frequent this bakery so often that the ladies behind the counter look for my son each time he is not with me!  They either ask where he is or if the order for him!  Cute!

Their baked goods are always fresh, tasty and are presented in such a way that is "fancy" in my eyes!  Within our neighborhood Fancy has the best tasting products.  I'm sure there are other bakeries in other hoods that would exceed the standards, but we are talking about San Bruno Avenue...a place riddled with produce markets, nail shops and an overwhelming amount of people!  So, a busy self serve bakery like Fancy Wheat Field, is definitely a refreshing option to the other businesses that loiter or neighborhood!

I've also provided the staff at the salon where I work an assortment of all of their personal sized dessert options for monthly birthday celebrations...they seem to favor Fancy Wheat Field Bakery just as much as my son!  Annnnnd this past Saturday, we hosted a  gathering for 57-60 people and offered the hot dog buns and ham and egg buns to our guests.  All of the buns were gone in no time.

If you ask me about my fave baked goody here...I prefer the Custard Bun.  It's a great pairing with a cup of coffee!!!
author: Candy R.

description: Wow, gruff customer services. Makes Sheng Kee seems downright friendly. But the breads are cheap and tasty. Particularly, the red bean infused bread had just the right ratio of bread to red bean and the milk buns (like giant oval marshmallows) had the most amazing texture between angel food cake and marshmallow.
author: Alexander J.

description:
If you read my two previous reviews you'll already know that I practically live off of this bakery, but it turns out that all of my really favorite items are located inside the refrigerated box near the cashier station.  Here is my latest update:

Coffee Cake Slice (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/xZy6wcfJLd2nT6RHq9Dm_w/l) - The cream is typical of that from many Chinese bakeries in that it is barely sweet and almost slightly salty.  The multiple layers of cake had a subtle flavor of sweetened coffee.  The cake is quite dry.

Chocolate Cake Slice (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/xsVDFSueB8Vs7X3fg_0wWg/l) - One can tell by its color that it is not very chocolatey.  The cake is very similar to that of the coffee cake slice but with a faint chocolate flavor instead.  The layer of whipped cream and powdered cocoa on top definitely help the overall taste of the cake.

Tiramisu Cake Slice (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/n_qFtt4VrFVj78Sg20BACg/l) - One layer of each of the coffee and chocolate cakes are used with lots of whipped cream.  The whipped cream is nicely flavored and definitely helps in moistening both layers of cake.  The only thing that I wished for was a dash of liqueur but that's easy, I can do that at home.

Strawberry Cake Slice (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/Trja5yLPO59eoRh2-HBPYw/l) - I like this one a lot.  It's very simple.  It's a rolled cake (like a jelly roll) with a moist, soft sponge cake, whipped cream and fresh strawberries.  Delicious!

Mixed Fruit Cake Slice (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/ZvB05gXLLxULcEricfuTJg/l) - I imagine their whole cakes are similar to this.   This is my favorite cake slice.  The soft sponge cake is used in this one too also with whipped cream, canned peach segments, fresh kiwi and fresh strawberries.  It is topped with more fresh fruit.  Yummy!

Fresh Fruit Mini Tart (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/TjBDqmibcr04dewiVTsy1Q/l) - They have these in full size tarts also.  It's a simple pie crust with a big dollop of custard cream in the center.  Canned peach slices are arranged on top along with fresh strawberries, blueberries, kiwi, a blackberry and a cantaloupe ball.  All of the fruit is held together by a thin film of sweetened clear gelatin.  Another favorite!

Mango Chocolate Mousse (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/C2bstQqEeUIxunsF6VldZQ/l) - It looks great but didn't taste very good.  Oddly enough they've stuck a chocolate cake slice in the middle of the whipped up mousse.  The mousse had zero mango flavor though and just tasted like sweetened, rich cream.  The chewy gelatin on top had no mango flavor either.  Nice to look at though!

Orange Berry Mousse (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/OYRfWMN0mD0K7rLWwf3ujQ/l) - I liked this one much more.  The flavors on the two mousses are very distinct - one orange, one strawberry.  There's a thin layer of chewy strawberry gelatin on top.

Mixed Fruit Cup (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/BxbH63JSYulMwPtUXGMnDg/l) - It's another one of my favorites.  The bottom of the dessert is Asian rainbow jelly.  An assortment of mixed fruits in soft gelatin is layered on top of the jelly.  Then comes the whipped cream, a layer of the soft sponge cake and another layer of whipped cream.  Surprisingly light and very tasty!

Mixed Fruit and Jellies Boat (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/ySNIcCF94_9QRONX96lWpg/l) - They sell out of these often and for good reason.  Beautiful to look at and refreshing to eat.  I don't understand why they don't use the mousse in this dessert for the mango chocolate mousse.  The bottom layer of the boat is mango mousse mixed with a little gelatin.  The mango flavor is excellent.  Strawberry gelatin and a layer of rainbow jelly complete the boat layers.  Up top is a dollop of whipped cream, fresh fruits and both dark and white chocolate ornaments.  I keep going back to look for this only to be told that I have to wait because they're all gone.  Worth the wait!
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: Ah.. and this place fails to keep up its quality. It's still better than most places but I can taste a difference in the recipes from when they first opened. I really hope they realize if they keep changing the recipe for the worse the review will keep going down. They're still nice people. I just want the old recipe back.
author: Shirlene K.

description: This place was literally amazing when I was walking around in the store with a sticky pork bun, but it's the gift that keeps giving as each new package we open is better than the last amazing treat. Go! Go my friends and EAT!
author: Aaron C.

description:
Pork sung bun with the ham and green onions and cream/mayo mix is on point. Though the buns here are on the pricier side, they are good. The place looks clean and there's a large variety of baked goods. After trying it for the first time, I would make my way there every weekend or make my sweet uncle go there for me just so I can load up on those buns. 

Tried the tiramisu cake, my family loved it, but i thought it was okay. Waiting for someone's birthday to give me an excuse to try the mango cake.
author: Tina S.

description: I'm Mexican, so I love panaderias, but these Chinese bakeries are gonna give my people a run for their money.  They have amazing baked goods here.  We had a taro filled sweet, a red bean filled sweat, and a mango strawberry mousse that was out of this world.  Bring your cash though! They don't accept credit cards :(
author: Gabriel M.

description:
We tried a smattering of buns this morning. They all weren't really any more special or different than the ones from other Chinese bakeries. They had a better presentation, but taste wise, not much more impressive. I would say they had some buns that you typically don't see at other places, like the Frankfurter, tomato hot dog, and the pork sung roll. 

I didn't like the fact that the red bean bun had whole beans and they mixed up the signs for the products. As a result, our custard bun was the cocktail bun. 

At the price point, head down the street to Red House Bakery for the same items which will be cheaper, bigger and tastier. 

I didn't try the cakes, so maybe that's the offering that makes this place with going to?
author: K. S.

description:
One of my customers mentioned this place as THE place to get asian baked goods. Thanks Irene, you rock! It's one of the best discoveries I've come across in awhile. 

I tried the gee-yuk song bau (pork song bun) and it was just sooooooo good (insanely great as Steve Jobs always said). You can't go wrong with savory pork and pork fat within folds of delicate bread. So moist and just so damn good. 

They have other impressive selections that my head was just spinning. Get here early for the best availability, as several of their items sell out. It's gonna be a permanent bookmark location for me.

Funny name that "fancy wheat field". It works.
author: Derek N.

description: OMG!!!!!! I grew up in Chinatown and this place makes THE BEST BUNS EVVVVEEEERRRRR!!!!! Today is my last day of eating meat/milk products. So understandably, I had to eat as much of these DELICIOUS  soft, fluffy, bake to perfection with LOVE meat  buns as possible, even though it's almost 11pm. Yums. It's sooo good!!!I hope they have something VEGAN here to eat. Everything is just sooo good!!!!!yummmmmmmmsssssss!!!!
author: Lisa F.

description:
Complete disappointment.  

Everything LOOKS really good, but that's about the only good thing about this place.  

My family bought a bunch of different items, so I was able to sample a lot of them.  Fruit tart had a hard, burnt-tasting shell and was filled with whipped cream (rather than custard that I'm used to).  They have three different types of cheesecake -- all of them were dry and virtually tasteless.  The pineapple buns were completely stale.  What a waste of calories.  =(

The service was just as bad.  They were completely stingy about giving boxes and insisted on throwing most items into a bag.  I guess we could pay the extra 50 cents for a box, but they have a sign up that says you get a box with a minimum of 10 items purchased -- we easily bought 40+ items (large family).  When my family protested the fact that they bagged things instead of boxing them, the workers said we need to take it up with the owner, who was right there in the store stocking, but completely ignored us.  Seriously, if your customers buy a bunch of stuff and want a few boxes, is it really that big of a deal?

CASH ONLY.
author: Anna C.

description:
Not too shabby Portola! Fancy Wheat Field Bakery is a great addition to this district because honestly, not many establishments here are the best :/ I got sucked into this place out of curiosity when I wanted something cheap to eat, and of course, asian buns are cheap!

They have a number of different buns here and many range around $.75 to about $2, more so averaging $1.20. I love the pork sung baos, ALL OF THEM! They have a pork sung and ham bao, pork sung and seaweed bao, and i think 2 other types. I love the cheese and garlic bread! The garlic flavor just makes my mouth water:) 

They also have mango cakes here, light cheese cakes, and other types of breads! Its pricier than what I'm use to paying, but I have yet to find another place as satisfying as this.
author: Connie C.

description: The breads are soft.  I like the coconut creme/loaf bread with raisin.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Delicious WEDDING CAKE!

We went cake tasting at a number of places for our wedding cake.  Although this place doesn't advertise that they do wedding cakes, they absolutely do!  And why not?  Their usual stuff is fabulous and delicious!

We got a 3 layer cake, 3 different flavors--green tea, tiramisu, and chestnut.  Everyone loved the cake!  It was soft, moist, and not too sweet.  We knew we wanted a mousse cake but most places we inquired with said they could not make a layered mousse cake, not even the fancy and expensive cake places.  Fancy Wheat Field has it figured out!  We got a beautiful and delicous 3 layer cake for a much better price than most cake places.

They also delivered our cake across the bridge for a bit of a fee.
author: Christine C.

description: This place was conveniently open early (I believe 7am to 7pm). What I was interested in finding a cake for my boyfriend's birthday. I am not from the area, but finding the place was quite easy (the sign on the front of the store was fairly big). I found parking quite easily (however, granted I did go early in the morning). When I entered, the cakes were all located near the register in a chilled casing. There were other pastries available as well. I decided to go with a chocolate mouse cake (which ended up being about 20 something dollars). The lady at the register bundled the cake up nice and securely in a cute box. The box was tied in a cute pink bow (which made carrying the box to my car so convenient!) After opening the box I later found that included with the cake was a package full of small plastic forks, small plates, a cake cutter, and even candles!) I was so impressed with all the extra bonuses. The cake tasted great though, sweet and fluffy, and the fruits tasted so fresh! The presentation of the cake was unique and definitely picture worthy! The only downfall to this business would be that they ONLY ACCEPT CASH (so make sure to stop by the ATM before coming in) and the street parking.
author: Charlene B.

description: I am giving a two star for their service. The ladies there are so rude and they have such bad customer service. Do not stand close to their bread or else they think your going to touch it with your hand.
author: Gia C.

description:
Oh you FANCY huh??

They most certainly are. Besides their deliciously baked goodies, their mousse cakes are the BEST I EVER HAD!! Beautiful decorated with fruits, thick piece of white chocolate and mousse upon mousse upon mousse.
author: Anonymous P.

description:
I have a thing for Chinese buns. Like hey, can I squeeza squeeza them? 

Their bread is super soft like pillowy and has a light hint of sweet. I know this because I just pulled two slices out of the bag and the bread was giving my finger a marshmallow/michelin man kind of snugglehug. 

I've yet to try their pork sung, but that's next on my list.. ooh.. and desserts of course.
author: Donna H.

description:
This is my favorite spot for hot dog buns.

Located near my parents house in the Visitation Valley location.

They have a lot of different cakes too, and buns, they always seem to be fresh, with lots of customers going in and out on a weekend morning/afternoon that they rotate quickly.

Must try the ham and egg and hot dog and egg tart.

I heard about the Golden Gate Bakery but I would rather stop by hear.
author: Harry T.

description:
a good bakery to go to when stopping by this area. the food always seems fresh, the cashiers fast and efficient. the food are displayed out in little cubbies and you grab what you want, put it on a tray and go up to the cashier. she will then put it in a box and ring you up in a timely manner. 

got the egg tart here and was very satisfied. especially since I've been craving an egg tart for the longest time now. ate one in the morning and was still good till lunch 
totally would come back. 


their cakes are not bad either.
author: Janne Y.

description:
One day I came home to a table of fancy cute looking baos! To my surprise, my grandma bought them from Fancy Wheat Field. =) I'm so happy they opened this bakery on San Bruno Ave!

The pork sung and ham bao is delicious! My brother goes here JUST for the pork sung & ham bao. I haven't tried many of the other baos yet...

however, I LOVEEE THEIR CAKES! I bought a FRESH MANGO CAKE (see pictures) from here for my brother's birthday. I got really lucky since the lady brought it out fresh from the back! It was the best mango cake I've ever had. FRESH fruits & mango slices on top and with FRESH MANGO inside. If you ever see a mango cake, I recommend that you buy it! (but I'm sure its only seasonal)

I also got the green tea mousse cake from here. I usually don't prefer mousse cakes, but the green tea caught my attention. It was also really good! My new favorite mousse cake! =)

Overall, their cakes haven't failed me. They're not too sweet and DELICIOUS!... and only for $22-$25. I'll definitely be coming here for more birthday cakes and BAOS! 

Another plus side to their delicious treats, when you buy a whole cake, they give you this complimentary cute little set of plates, forks, cake cutter, and candles! They'll offer it when you buy a cake, if not... just ask!
author: Thomas Y.

description:
One of my favorite Chinese bakeries in the city. They have the best wife cakes (winter melon cake / lo po bang / lao po bing)!!!

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
It's a small little shop with only 2 small tables. The store is in the middle of the block, and can be hard to see. Even more difficult is parking on the weekends. I tried some of the things I read about on other Yelp reviews. 

The dan-ta (egg tarts) were decent. Flakey crusts, and not too sweet custard was great. But it was pretty oily and I could feel the fat sinking in to me...

Green tea mousse was just ok. Nothing special. a bit on the plastic tasting side. 

Mango cake was very pretty but too sugary. It's not a blatant sweetness, but I noticed that none of us could finish or single slice. Bad sign. It was good at first but was left with the taste of sugar in my mouth. It was an odd hidden sugar type of cake. 

But the bakery is in a location with no other good Chinese bakeries, so it's a good options when I'm in the area. Also, they do live up to their Fancy name with their very pretty cake boxes. Very sturdy, beautifully printed, with a cute ribbon. It looked like a cute hat box. 

I'll have to try their meat buns and breads next time I'm in the area.
author: Leslie Y.

description: Their bread is so good. It's a great gift for families. Also love their milk tea. They sometimes run out of milk tea right around they close.
author: Michelle S.

description: The bakery that has something for everyone! These inexpensive and delicious pastries (and cakes!) are made fresh daily. This is the go to place to pick up a whole fruity cake for birthdays, graduations, and more!
author: Fanny T.

description:
I came here a LONG time ago and just decided to post this review now.

But this place has the best bao in the freaking world. This place is esteemed as a Chinese bao bakery and definitely doesn't disappoint. It has more of a modern, Hong Kong-style feel; you grab a tray and grab the types of bread you want. The bread is already pre-packaged, and I came on the occasion where they were warm and fresh out of the oven! 

I got a Pork Sung bao. it was soft, covered with pork sung all around the roll. Most of all, I got it when it was WARM. Nothing beats that. 

I also ended up getting a variety of standard baos: Char Siu bao, Hot Dog bao, etc. I had these when they were cold, but it was still good. The bread was nice and soft, easy to eat. The meat inside the Char Siu bao was VERY good. It was plentiful and didn't taste artificial. The hot dog was just a hot dog. Uh, what can I really say about it?

The prices for these baos are pretty good. They tend to be a little more expensive than average - and I consider the average to be like, 60-70 cents - but for the quality and freshness, it's great.

Also, someone told me that they noticed a lot of people working in the back (who actually make the bread). That's interesting, since there was only one person at the cash register. With that many people in the back, they could at least put another person out front. We had to wait in line to pay because people wanted the best baos ever. But I can't blame them - this place is great! I will be back to fulfill my bao cravings. Yum.
author: Nancy C.

description:
EDIT:  Here's a tip, if you need a cake in a larger size (than the standard round 8") or anything custom besides maybe a basic decoration change, they may require you to order at least 1 week in advance. 

Better than Sheng Kee. Their fresh mango cake is probably my favorite Asian cake to pick up for birthdays now. Would it be weird if I bought the same cake for consecutive birthdays?
author: C. Z.

description: Most likely my favorite Chinese bakery in the SF area. Consistently good breads and flavors and amazing price. I love going here when I'm in the area for a quick cheap bite. Their cakes are great too and the cashiers get the line going efficiently Chinese style.
author: Rachel T.

description:
I got a "Just a Note" compliment  from  Cherylynn N. the other day sayin':
"Have you tried Fancy Wheat Bakery in Portola? If not, YOU MUST. Their pork sung bun is amazing!"
I think she felt very sorry reading my Sheng Kee Bakery's 2 star review.
So I went FWFB down that San Bruno Ave near by candlestick.

Chinese bakery is not really hit and miss kinda thing in SF because it's too many. Most of them are OK, edible, but, it's very hard to find a really good one.

When I walked in the store, I was like, "HolyFXXX, it's same as Sheng Kee!"
I was expecting an Old Chinese Chinatown like Chinese Bakery type. O.C.C.C.B type. But it's same as Sheng Kee, you know, tongs and tray, you pick it up by your self kind, I hate it because I always get too many and I felt sorry afterwards.

So, I was very disappointed, fail to fulfill the hopes or expectations.
At the same time, is this some kind of joke? How can I write review?
I was seriously thinking even though I didn't get anything yet.

So, I looked around, 
I picked 1 pork sung bun, I was like, " OK, this is the thing what Cherylynn N. was talking about, FXXX, it looks like shit, well, just once, just once, and it's only 90 cents, not a big of deal."

Then, I saw the ham pork sung roll, I was like, "WTF? this is the most ugly shit i've ever seen, who eats a shit like this? Oh hell."

Then I saw the seaweed pork bun, I was totally shocked to see the label. I could not believe what I was reading. I stood up for a while, and I hear something sayin', "Take it, Nobu, take the shit, you'll regret if you don't get the shit."
I looked around, no one was there. But I really heard it.
After I picked up the frecken' seaweed pork bun, I said to myself, " Well, I think I should get something ordinary, simple, regular and I familiar with, Oh, BBq pork bun, and.... hey, red bean bun!"

So, I got 3 totally almost illegal funky lookin' Chinese pastries and 2 regular Chinese pastries.
5 of them, I payed $4.65, that was it.
It was 8 am, I parked my car right front. I was a bit hungry so I had the pork sung bun in my car. I am so glad that I was not driving. I think I might be hit something if I was driving, Yes, that good.
This shit is good.
All of them!

Pork Sung Bun is A BOMB, A KILLER! Dangerously addictive/heroin/crack like good! Indeed. salty sweet dried shredded pork with some kind of crunchy-ness, like a bitting sugar, I am not a big fan of cheap Chinese Super-Soft buns but this is something very special. It's very creative, smart idea who ever made the thing.

Ham Pork Sung Roll is second. Super ugly but Super Good.

Seaweed Pork Bun is ... it sounds like WTF? but Fxxxin' Owesome! Lovein' it.

BBQ Pork Bun. Good of course.

Red Bean Bun. Good. Its crunchy kind. I just notice that why non-Asian-Americans don't like sweet red bean paste? There is nothing wrong with red bean to be "sweet".

Hey, Cherylynn N. without your recommendation, I would not know.
The Best and Fanciest Chinese Bakery in SF!
Indeed.

I just wishing the FWFB has deep fried curry bun.
author: Nobu K.

description: Omg, A bakery that can represent Chinese bakeries as chic yet tasty! Also this place is cheaper & nearby! Unlike being overpriced like Bernal Heights & Noe Valley, this place doesn't fail to disappoint! The selection is fab & items are fresh. Just make sure to do AKT in motion or Tracy Anderson Method fitness as this place isn't ideal for dieters. It's self self but clean as compared to many self serve bakeries.
author: R C.

description:
Fancy Wheat Field: Meh. So-so baked goods and awkward customer service

I stopped by Fancy Wheat Field on a whim and popped into what seemed to be a very popular spot, as all of the tables were occupied and there was a line extending from the cash register to the door. Even if the business isn't terribly big, it was still impressive. Navigating around all the bodies, I grabbed a tray from the rear right of the shop and attacked the cases. Thanks to my panaderia experiences, this DIY style was familiar. I loaded up with a variety of sweet and salty buns but was still missing some pineapple buns, which will play an important part later. I jumped into line and thought it would be a quick affair.

NOPE. Apparently, each transaction will take a minimum of three minutes. I'm not really sure what happened that day, but the cashiers just took their sweet time in packing up everyone's purchases and making change. Luckily, in those seven odd minutes that I was waiting, I saw the bakers put a fresh rack of pineapple buns onto the cooling trays. NICE. When I checked out, I asked the cashier for one of the pineapple buns, but she said "No, we're out. Sorry." Cool. Maybe she didn't see them. I point them out to her and she turns around to tell me again, "No, sorry. No more." What? Really? At this point, I've spent about ten minutes in this godforsaken place; ten minutes that I will never get back. I told myself to forget it and just leave. Funny story: as soon as I step out of the store, the pineapple buns are loaded into the self-serve racks. Great. Awesome.

As for the goods that I did purchase? Meh. The buns tasted good, but they should considering how fatty and greasy they were. If you put enough butter or sugar into something, it better taste good.
author: Frank Y.

description:
This place is a true hidden gem!

We arrived an hour before the Color Run started, so my friends and I decided to get some milk tea. But, since that milk tea place wasn't opened, we started to explore around. And guess what we found?! This splendid place!

Don't let the hole in the wall ambiance deceive you because this little gem has many hidden secrets. We were only supposed to "look" around, but we couldn't help but give in to our sweet tooth. How can you say no to rows and rows of neatly-placed, sweet-smelling baked goods? And the price was just right! They were practically calling out our names.

The pineapple bun was nothing short of perfect! This little soft, round ball of sweet, sweet fluffiness was only 50 cents. AMAZING! I made the mistake of only buying one. I didn't even get a chance to get more of it because a man walked in and literally took the ENTIRE tray straight out of the display case, and immediately walked up to the cashier. 

Not only do they have all sorts of sweet and savory buns, but they also have a wide variety of beautifully crafted cakes (whole cakes and sliced pieces). One of my friends selected the tiramisu cake and she LOVED it! I didn't try it, but she did say that these layers of mocha and chocolate-flavored cake melted in her mouth--heavenly.

We parked a few blocks away (by Candlestick Park, which is about 1.7 miles away from this bakery), so we didn't have trouble looking for parking. But it looked like it was quite difficult to find street parking near this bakery. If you don't like looking for parking (and don't mind walking a bit further), there's plenty of street (non-metered) parking a couple of blocks away.
author: Jacque C.

description: You NEED to go to this place! Sooooooooooo good. Everything there is like $1-$3 and is worth the price. I always get this like "wiener inside a bun" snack. I think its a dollar but so delicious. There's also another Fancy in Downtown SF. And the mini chocolate cupcakes are soooooooooo good!!
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Even right after entering its noticeably cleaner than chinatown bakeries but wayy more expensive too ( and when talking about baos, several cents go a long long way) but after spending over $25 or so you get a VIP card that allows for 10% off your total each time you visit. 

Did i mention this place is a china styled self serve bakery? No need to be awkward in ordering a chicken tail bao ever again.

the buns range from 60 cents to $1.10 
the packages buns and mini cupcakes range from $1.50 to $3
the dessert cups are around $2.50 each

the prices may be high for a chinese bakery but the desserts are definitely plentiful in variety and accessorized with chocolate flowers and fruits galore.

I come to buy a fresh out of the oven bao but stick around to gawk at their attractive desserts
author: Wendy N.

description:
New and exciting, mind you a little fancy.

This bakery kicks others out of the competition in portola by far right now, let's hope the good continues! As for the top item here, it has to be the red bean bun, very smooth and flavorful, makes a happy snack.

The hot dog bun and coconut bun are also two great choices!
author: Ming S.

description: I enjoy the pastry selections here and the location is great. The ham pork sung roll is really good. Some other ones that you should definitely try are the wife cakes, green onion cheese bun, and the pork bun. I highly suggest that you give this place a try. The other bakeries in the area don't compare to the quality of the pastries here. It's a lot more convenient than going all the way to Chinatown.
author: Tim G.

description:
I really liked coming here because they let you grab your own buns. While, I'm picking for the choice buns, the workers are bringing out a tray of hot new buns. Of course, I'm gonna go for those as well! Grab 'em while you can!

They have a lot of great looking cakes and pastries as well, but I usually avoid that because it makes me feel more like a fatty.

A co-worker brought in some of their goodies the other day and I really liked their egg tarts as well.
author: Sam T.

description: My faves are the Macau tart or aka Po-Tat elsewhere. Once you try this, you will never go back to the Dan Tat! I also love the Bacon and Crab bun.  The pineapple buns are always perfectly crisp on top and soft and chewy inside. The kids like the mini chocolate muffins and the hot dog bun. The hubs like the coconut bun but gosh, everything is always fresh and most things are yummy here. The price is also better than most of like stores. Even their milk tea is brewed to perfection!
author: Ravenous T.

description:
Discovered this place while walking down San Bruno after having dim sum down the street.  My is parking a pain there...but the weather's so nice!

There's definitely a Sheng Kee-esque feel to this place; everything is laid out neatly behind little plastic doors, there are trays that you transfer the baked goods onto with tongs and there's a pretty wide variety cakes, buns, breads and "other".  I will say that it seems to me like the prices are cheaper than Sheng Kee and the quality is pretty much the same.  Actually, Sheng Kee seems to have shrunk everything lately; the lats time I walked in everything seemed slightly deflated :(

I'm giving this place five stars and it's based on the only thing I've ever had here, which I get every time: the 50 cent dinner rolls.  They're always nice and warm when I get them (around noon on Saturday, although they bring fresh ones out fairly frequently) and it's pretty hard to resist eating them right away.  They smell great, they're very soft and not overpoweringly sweet, thankfully.  I usually get about eight in one visit and pretty much finish half of them before I get home.

(By the way, apparently they're opening a location in Chinatown pretty soon, which I think will be on Stockton.)

I haven't tried many of the other things, although my mother usually gets the pork sung roll, which I find too "exotic" to try.  She says it's pretty good though and I suppose mother knows best.
