I will say that the other things in the display (sausage buns, egg tarts, that huge thing with the cheese and tomatoes) look great and smell even better.  All in all, I'd say this place wins on freshness, price and being pretty clean.
author: Jeffrey T.

description: I like this place. It is their first bakery. The one in Chinatown is their second ones. At least that I know of. Their sweet bread is good for sandwich. Their egg tart is alright. My family and I always order cakes from here for birthday too
author: Michael Q.

description:
Round 2 of my Chinese pastry binge.  The pastries here look so pretty that I just want to keep putting more on my tray.  And there's so much variety!  

* Strawberry yogurt cup ($2.50): This dainty little dessert starts at the top with a thin layer of strawberry gelatin, then a light, airy layer of strawberry mousse (faint in flavor) underneath, a somewhat bland, slightly sweet layer of dense chiffon cake, whipped cream with strawberries and another layer of cake on the bottom.  The fruit flavors could have been stronger.  Also, I have no idea where the yogurt was.

* White chocolate cakes:  Sold in a pack of two, these small oval shaped cakes were interesting but also somewhat bland. A thin layer of white chocolate covering a dense, slightly sweet chiffon cake.

* Ham & cheese bun (85 cents): Actually it seemed more like a ham and green onion roll. The dough was chewier than usual.  The ham bits were finely chopped.  Flavorful but too salty.   

* Nut cake ($2.75): It's like a giant sponge cupcake topped with almonds, slightly eggy taste, not too sweet, denser than usual, pretty good

Sunday afternoon was a good time to visit as they kept bringing out trays of fresh pastries.  If this was in my neighborhood, I'd pop in all the time.
author: Lolia S.

description: San Bruno Avenue version of Sheng Kee. Their prices are about the same, just not sure of the quality. They are trying to copy the success that Sheng Kee has gotten.
author: M C.

description: The breads are cute, and way cheaper than expected (coming from South Bay). The egg tarts are decently sized but maybe a 4/5 for the picky egg tart fan, but some of the other breads are pretty good.
author: Joy Y.

description:
Found out about this lovely bakery about 1 year ago when my co worker brought some of there bread back to work for us.
Most of the items are good but my favoutrite is the pork sung bun , its very soft and the amount of cream they use to stick the pork sung to is perfect. There hk style garlic cheese bread is pretty nice too.
Last time i went there myself and i am impressed with there milk tea. 
Cant wait till i am back next time. Yumm

Also , cash only folks !!
author: Ed B.

description: i've tried several of bus buns and it is not disappointing. This is pretty much comparable to Chinatown bakeries; cheap but delicious so whoever lives near here do not have to travel to Chinatown just for a bun. One star off for the lemon swiss roll because the lemon part is tooo sweet!
author: Allie Y.

description: Nothing that makes me scream "DELICIOUS" but it's a pretty nice place to get baked goods in the morning. I tried the thousand layer cake, the butterfly cookies, and the green tea roll. They were pretty good. I'd give this place a higher rating if the cashier were more friendly...
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Winter melon cookies were amazing! Buttery, flaky, crispy outside with soft melon filling. For ~$1, you get 4 cookies! It was really hard to resist eating all 4 in one sitting! Also tried the pineapple bun and coconut bun, both were soft and had just the right amount of sweetness. 

I'm glad I live far from this bakery or I would be here everyday! :D
author: Kara L.

description:
Ok, so I've been back multiple times since the first post.  My mom and sister have birthdays about a week apart, so we bought cakes for both of them.

Chocolate Cake - $18.  HELLA GOOD. The cake was light and not overly sweet.  The frosting wasn't heavy and I actually ate it (i NEVER eat frosting...).  It was topped with fruit and had chocolate pieces on the side.

Tiramisu - $22. Also REALLY good. It had less fruit than the Chocolate cake, but it was really yummy.  Topped with chocolate flowers and had strawberries on it.

We bought over $20 for the other cake and it came with a choice of a Fancy Wheat bakery hat or an apron. AWESOME. Incentives keep me coming!
author: Lily W.

description: I ordered a birthday cake here for my little brother. During the time that I ordered, they were talking crap about me in Chinese thinking I didn't understand. Second of all when I brought the cake home they had spelled my brothers name wrong. My brothers name is Tyler not Tyer. Even worse is that I spelled out his name for them on a piece of paper. Last but not least the cake was dry. It was obvious they made this cake two or three days before I had to pick it up. It was not worth almost $40 for this cake. I was to embarrassed to even take a picture of this cake because they couldn't even spell my brothers name right. Very disappointed with this place.
author: Karleen T.

description: This bakery reminds me of Honolulu.  The difference is that everyone working here is Chinese and not Japanese.  This is so similar to St. Germain however they have cha shui bow which is baked.  They also have very french pastries too.  The price is a bit pricey - and the service no matter how high end it is - when you have employees that speak Chinese - well what else can we say about 'service'.  I am a fan for their goodies but service is a level 3.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Today I went in there to buy BBQ bun and others bread. In the morning it was very busy.  However, the customers service there is very RUDE...all they does it speaks Chinese. When you asks anything...they reply" I dont speak English"  WTH.  When I reach the cashier to pay. The cashier did not say anything...when she gaves back my chances she throw it down on the counter.  Very bad service and RUDE.  i AM SURE EVEN THEY HAVE VERY GOOD FOOD. i WONT EVEN COME BACK EVER...
author: Megan L.

description:
It's always nice to see new business starting in the Portola and San Bruno Ave area.

This new bakery is a self serve type bakery. You get a tray and pick out their pastries, buns, and cakes. 

The only bad thing is that it is a very small store and can get really packed sometimes, like in the mornings. 

And they some times run out of trays, and if they do, you will look stupid and just stand there and wait. Or just use your hand to hold it. 

Also the little cabinets that hold the bake goods are not the most efficient. You have to lift the door all the way up to a certain spot to hold it up and all the while you have to hold the tray and tong! 

Overall, the bake goods are tasty, moist, and fresh. I haven't tried the cakes yet, but from the looks of it and other's review, it seem to be pretty good.

I am glad there's a self serve bakery in this neighborhood. I hope this business continue with its success and thrive because the neighborhood and San Francisco needs it.
author: U L.

description:
This place is great, they actually speak English here so no qualms about a missing order or getting the wrong cake. I like that it's a small neighborhood place, so none of that snooty bum-rush feel to it. 

They're smart, their buns are all on display to the street. Great marketing to get you inside their doors. But really, how could you pass them up?! Their buns look amazing!! And they don't have just the standard stuff, they have their own creations, which is why I would def be returning here. 

They have many variations of pork sung buns, but too bad the ham & pork sung roll one has mayo in the center! blech!! but not to worry, it's a roll, so i happily unrolled it and wiped it all off to still enjoy it. Not like most places, there's no removing the mayo. You wipe it off and there goes all your pork sung! 

Their single serving mousse desserts looked so pretty and delish! Their baked cheesecake was light and airy, really reminded me of Jap cheesecake. It had the perfect balance of flavor without being too sweet and having baked it, gave it the slightest crisp of an edge. (Drooling yet?!)

I wished they had a few more selection of cake flavors but all good, because the strawberry mango mousse cake I got, was a hit at the party. It wasn't too sweet and very light. Not to mention it was really pretty with the fresh fruits and decoration. 

It truly distinguishes itself from all the other asian bakeries because of their own variations of buns. Otherwise, it would just be "another asian bakery." Not to mention, their cake box is really nice and sturdy. It is an actual box with a lid (picture a hat box...but for cake!) which came with shoe-lace like ties, making it easy to transport and repack the leftovers. Not only that, but they included a cute bday set with plastic cake knife, forks, skinny candles and mini plates. Everything you need with no charge!! 

Great addition to the neighborhood, I am impressed and hope you stay!!
author: Ly T.

description: I'm impressed by the red bean buns and the fresh quality of the breads. Went by around 530pm on a weeknight and there was still fresh breads coming out of the oven. The cakes in the cold case were very on par with the other bakeries that serve cream and fruit cakes, but for convenience again, being right off of 101 vs. deep in the heart of the sunset district, this place is a gem.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Though their bread is good .... unless you are Chinese they treat you terrible, last time I will ever visit. I wanted a BBQ pork bun and they were out at the case but I just saw them put some fresh ones on the rack and told me they would be ready in 10 min...
author: A D.

description:
They deserve a 2 star just for their pork sung bao!!! That bao is bomb, i tell you! B-O-M-B!! It is a bao with creamy filling inside. On the outside, it has pork sung and onions. it sounds like a pretty tasty bao already, don't you agree? 

HOWEVER, the bad always comes with the good right? The big downside of this place is that the baos are only good if are fresh... Or else it will not be the BOMB.... It won't last longer than 24 hours, unlike other Chinese bakeries which you can have your baos sitting for at least 2 days.
author: Daniel L.

description: I've never been to Fancy Wheat Field Bakery (what a mouth full, huh?) before, but I had a cake from here last weekend for my nephew's party. IT WAS SO GOOD and I don't even like Chinese cakes. It was a mocha cake topped with chocolate flowers and leaves, and strawberries. The cake was light, moist, and most importantly, not too sweet. The mocha flavor wasn't too overbearing either. I overheard that the cake only costs $12, but I don't believe it. THAT'S STRAIGHT UP ROBBERY. I'm not sure, so don't go in the store and say that I told you the cakes were $12.
author: Audrey T.

description: Wow, so cheap!  Clean and lots of variety although King's cocktail buns still have a slight edge!  Parking sucks and there's usually a line but definitely recommend and would come here again.
author: kiwi l.

description:
MUST GET THEIR GREEN TEA MOUSSE CAKE!

Inexpensive
Taste great!
Presentation is lovely
Texture is light and fluffy
You will NOT want to stop eating!

I want to try all the other cakes!
author: Jennifer D.

description: Pork sung buns!! I could eat those all day, every day! Best i've ever had in SF! Definitely a must-try if you're in the area and can find parking!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
This place is quite pricey for some buns, compared to other places. Everything looks so appealing walking past this place, especially when it's dark out because everything is so bright in there. 

Tried this place out just for the heck of it and it wasn't bad. The cheese ham roll (I think that's what it's called) is definitely worth a try! I'd prefer the slightly browner ones since I like a little toasty taste. Too bad it's a whole dollar for 1 or I would be coming here for this bun alone.

 I think these buns are only worth buying if you're going to eat them right away or else they just won't be as good. I personally don't come here often because I'm not a big fan of buns, but this place isn't half bad. 3 stars for prices!
author: Hui L.

description:
This is my new found Hong Kong bakery aka heaven. I swear I could have been born a Jew because I love bread *that* much. 

Their pineapple bread fresh from the oven is fabulous given that it is plain ole pineapple bread. My all-time delectable is their cheese-ham-(scallion) roll. Sounds like an approved Atkins item HOWEVER my fellow Yelpers... you are in for a treat!! Please try it! It's oh so delicious and the underdog item of the bakery. The place is clean and small and for what you get (ambiance, clean, cute and well put together packaging) it is a fair price.

Posted some pics too..check it out!
author: Judy N.

description:
Really, I don't get why this place got such raving reviews.

All the pastries are solid, the place are clean, and like many other Chinese bakeries in LA or South bay, you use the tray to pick what you want and pay at the end. The regular morning breakfast buns and their cake are good and fresh. Cake are just like most Chinese bakeries, light and not too sweet.

The good thing is they have coffee and HK style milk tea ($2)
author: Alice C.

description:
I used to hit this place up all the time.. until they were extremely rude to me. Haven't been back since. Their deserts are yummy, used to always take them back home for my family in the East Bay. What a shame, I'll never go back.

Bottom line- great bakery, slightly over-priced, REALLY BAD customer service. Oh yeah, and parking is a hassle. 

Come here if your don't mind dirty looks and bad customer service in exchange for delicious but over-priced deserts.
author: Jessica R.

description: The Pork Sung ROLLS (not bun) is soooooo yummy. Can't find the same ones anywhere else.
author: Meta D.

description:
I super love this place. Super super duper. My auntie discovered this place and shared with us. She brought the pork sung bun over one day, and I had to go buy more!

I found that they had mini wifey cookies. They're cheap and absolutely AMAZING. Must buy. GO NOW.
author: Erica A.

description: We ordered the mango cake same day and they were able to fulfill the order in less than 4 hours!  The cake was SO pretty.  Even the "happy birthday" message they wrote on the chocolate looked really good.  The cake was very soft and fresh.  There were a lot of fruits on it.  The quality is of the higher end Chinese bakeries and comparable to the higher end American style bakeries.  But the prices are reasonable compared to American style bakery.  Only $26.
author: e c.

description:
I was waiting across the street from Fancy Wheat Field Bakery at the 9 stop. It was a tedious wait in a sketchy neighborhood, so I went inside to grab a cup of coffee because the outside banner looked pretty eye-catching and the place looked really clean.

Stepping inside, I immediately am reminded of the bakeries in HK and Guangzhou, China. They have the grab-a-tray-and-pair-'ol-tongs-and-pick-what-your- heart-desires set up, the individual cellophane wrapped pastries, the authentic wafting scent of something wonderful being baked in the back, and EVEN the bakery girl in matching apron and handkerchief headband a la Cooking Mama! This place is like heaven!

I went a little overboard like a kid in a candy store. I was a piggy in a bakery! I was overwhelmed by the classic offerings that I thought I could only get every 4 years I could travel to HK. These pastries are more expensive than places like Golden Gate Bakery or ABC but definitely worth it!

I ended up getting two of each: caterpillar custard loaf, taro pastries, rooster tail bun, angel cheesecake, milk cake, and a cup of coffee.

So far, I tried the caterpillar custard loaf, the filling has an amazing air-whipped texture and the bread itself was soft and has the perfect sweetness to it. Not too sweet, but not bland neither!

The taro pastries were also amazing. They were actually layered into tiny paper tin...layers! These aren't like those boxed pastries with a piece of dough with filling inside. They flake and fall apart like any pastry worth it's salt does. Like the weirdo I often am, I took apart one pastry to count the number of layers...113 layers of yummy, purple taro goodness!

I think I found a new food crush. I know for sure I'm gonna find excuses to migrate towards San Bruno in order to satisfy my cravings for Taro pastries and caterpillar custard loafs. :)
author: Anna F.

description:
Receiving deserving hype from the yelpers. A massive emporium of baked goods - breads, cookies, buns, you name it. So many options I was a bit skeptical everything was made in house, but I was assured that was indeed the case.

Impressive.

After taking time narrowing down my selections (not easy), I went with some wheat bread and a honey comb cookie/pie concoction of some sort.

Equally impressive.
author: Jason B.

description: I really like their sesame cookies, which they already pre-package.  I just go in, grab a bag and go.  It's a typical self-serve bakery.  You pick up a tray and fill it.  I get the Hong Kong tea to-go from the ladies.  Everything is fresh and the place is clean.
author: Helen L.

description:
My parents bought me bread when I told them I was looking for a new place for bo lo bao.  They also bought baked bbq pork buns which my honey LOVED.  

I recently came back to buy him more baked bbq pork buns and got myself a red bean bread.  It was sooo good.  Smooth red bean on soft slightly chewy bread.

This part of San Bruno Ave is not so bad in terms of finding street parking.
author: J T.

description:
I swear I'm here every week, buying Pineapple buns. YUM! Especially when you get them fresh and piping hot right out the oven, the only thing is that quirky crumbly top that tastes NOTHING like Pineapple. There's sweetness to it, but no inkling of pineapple flavor. And how can you hate on a dozen for $6, of course you're welcome to only buy one at 50cents, which still isn't bad. My son loves to have his school sandwiches on them the next day!

I've also had the pork sung roll, which is good until you get that surprise mayonnaise action in the middle. Lol. I think it could be PERFECTLY fine without it.

The pork buns are actually very good too, the best ones on San Bruno Ave IMHO and a decent value at 90cents without having to drive into Chinatown. There's a good ratio of bun:meat!

My girls love the coconut "custard" bun and mom says the red bean bun is decent too.

Tried a slice of the fresh mango cake and the nice thing is for being an individual slice it hasn't lost its moisture. Mangoes aren't in season yet tho so they were a bit tart and didn't quite match the cake.

Nice addition to a rather eclectic neighborhood. San Bruno Ave has so many random stores and restaurants on it, Fancy Wheat Field is definitely a step in the right direction, if only some of the other stores and store fronts can be as inviting.
author: Dina V.

description:
I love the pork bun there. 
I'm getting a cake there for my sis birthday. When I'm hungry I just go there and get the best food ever for my stomach.
author: Teresa T.

description:
I actually live near this bakery. My family comes here to buy pastry all the time. We have a VIP membership here. I love the pastries here. It is a bit pricey compared to other bakeries but I will always come back. 

The dried shredded pork bun is the best because it is moist and soft filled with a salt sweet cream. It is to die for.

The cakes are so exquisite and delicious. Light and creamy. You must come and try the pastry.
author: Christopher W.

description: This place is awesome for a small hole-in-the wall bakery.   And I stress VERY small... since most people bump into each other while trying to grab their pastries and etc.  I blame my buddy Bobby for introducing me to this place and ever since... I have stopped by here like almost each day on my way to work to get my desert fix on!!  Love Love Love their ridiculously balanced and flavorful BBQ Pork Buns... I am in Hog Heaven!!!  I must confess that I buy more than just one!!!  Their chocolate mouse and mango cakes are to die for!!!  Pretty much everything is good here since I practically tried every item for the last few months!!  (mental note, need to go exercise and burn all of it off).
author: Tony T.

description: All of their pastries and Chinese buns are baked fresh daily and they bring it out for the customers to choose themselves. I mainly come to this bakery for their fresh and perfect size pineapple buns and not watered down nor over-sweetened hot milk tea. The pineapple bun bread is nice and soft with a good amount of the "pineapple" crust for the perfect sweetness of the bun. Who does not like fresh baked buns?! The hot milk tea is not like the boba/tapioca places in which the milk teas are always watered down, too much milk/half-n-half, and too much sugar. This bakery's milk tea has a good ratio of tea to milk, in which I can taste the tea bitterness with some sweetness too. This makes me want to go get some pineapple buns with hot milk tea!
author: Shirley M.

description:
First of all, I just have to say: HOLY F***ING MOUTHGASM!!

Alright, now that I've gotten that out of the way, I must delve into the back story illustrating the chain of events that led me to this heavenly place.  I actually live in Denver, which has an extremely minimal Asian population. Thus, the culinary experience suffers heavily.  So when my Taiwanese mom heard that I was driving my dumpy Subaru to San Francisco to hang out for a month, she didn't hesitate to email me a massive grocery list of food that she somehow expected to last the 22 hour drive back.  Her biggest priority was for me to get loaves and loaves of Chinese style white "toast" bread.  She's an accomplished baker of Chinese pastries herself, but has never felt that she was able to master that style of bread. I was skeptical about whether or not the bread would last in a hot car with no working air conditioning for 1,200 + miles, especially since I was planning on staying with a friend in Vegas. She insisted it would be fine as long as I threw it in a freezer whenever I had a chance. Apparently they can last pretty long in the freeze. 

I made a list of four of the highest rated Chinese bakeries on Yelp and visited them all the day before I left.  I grabbed loaves from every single place. As I was making my way out of town this was my absolute last stop.  I was a little skeptical of the sketchy location (forgive me if it's not actually that sketchy.. I'm a Denverite) but all my concerns were alleviated the second I walked in.  Growing up in Asia and having had my fair share of Chinese pastries, I know the good stuff when I see it. I knew I had to buy more than one loaf from this bakery.  I bought four.  I also caved and got a couple treats for myself. Every single thing I bought tasted amazing.  I hadn't had quality like this since being in Taiwan.  The cake in particular was ridiculous.  Absolutely ridiculous. I didn't even know it was possible to make cake that light and airy and still so super moist. Wow. I threw all the loaves in the freezer that night.  

My journey back to Denver began at 4am the next day, I was exhausted and about 5lbs heavier due to excess pastries. You might ask why I left so early if I was planning to spend the night in Vegas.  Well, that's because I decided to get creative and take a detour through Death Valley. Yes, Death Valley in my car that didn't have a working heater, with about ten loaves of Chinese bread in the trunk.  I made it to Vegas, stuffed the bread in my friends freezer and decided to stay and party for a few days before heading back to Colorado.  I was mildly concerned at the quality of the bread my mom was going to get by the time I got home, especially being that she's highly picky.  At that point the bread had sat in a freezer for a day, in an extremely hot car for ten hours, a freezer for another three days and then the car for over ten more hours.

I waited anxiously as my mom took the first bite of the bread.  She paused for a moment, then said just one word: "Wow". (In Mandarin it's more like "Waaa" but bear with me).  She then proceeded to tell me that it was the best Chinese style toast bread she's ever had, even beating out anything she's ever had in Taipei. Together we tested out the loaves from all the different bakeries. Nothing compared, and a couple of them didn't last well during the trip. The Fancy Wheat Field Bakery loaves held up perfectly and tasted amazing.

So there you have it. Tested and proven. This place is phenomenal.  So phenomenal in fact, that I am probably not going to tell my mother the next time I'm going to be in San Francisco, because I know she's going to make me pay Fancy Wheat Field a visit...  And I know that if I ever set foot in that place again, I will probably eat their entire display case and my waistline can't take that sort of punishment. Don't judge me.  Where I live, the best quality of baked goods you can get is a doughnut at a strip mall... or if you're brave enough to drive into the dodgiest area of town you might be lucky enough to get a stale pineapple bun on your way to the pawn shop.
author: Lana P.

description: This isn't a review for their cakes since I have not tried them. This is a review for their pineapple bun and walnut cookie. Let's just say if I have the craving for a pineapple bun I will drop by but the best is still at Sheng Kee's.
author: Helen L.

description: Excellent desserts and competitive pricing.  This small bakery has an assortment of sweet breads, pastries and desserts.  Their desserts are delicious and give Sheng Kee a lot of competition.
author: Nicole C.

description:
I was very hesitant to try Fancy Wheat Field Bakery when they first opened probably over a year ago. But my mom was not, she tried it and told me it was good and that they even had Portuguese egg tarts, which I have not been able to find elsewhere in the city. 

The biggest difference between Portuguese egg tarts and normal egg tarts is that the Portuguese egg tart has a caramelized coating over the egg custard. It is sweeter and very delicious. Although they are smaller and more expensive than normal egg tarts, it is a nice change every so often. 

Their other pastries are also pretty good, not the best in the city but probably the best in the area. They have all the traditional baked goods including red bean bread, pineapple bun, cocktail bun and much much more.
author: Angela T.

description:
This review should have come a lot sooner, but I've kept putting it off, and off, and off...until now.

This is only one of 2 bakeries worth going to on San Bruno Avenue (the other being Red House Bakery -- a review for that coming soon). I've been here many, many times and have tried a variety of baos -- the hot dog bao, yok soong bao (the one with the shredded pork thing, ham, and green onion), the bao with coconut, the pineapple bun, the bao with ham, cheese, and green onion, etc. etc. (As you can tell, my Cantonese stinks, so bear with me.) Good quality for a good price. (I am just in love with their baos, in case you didn't notice!)

The place is self-serve (another plus!), which kind of reminds me of Sheng Kee on Irving in the Sunset (only half self-serve). I love how you can pick the best looking baos for yourself and leave the burnt ones for the unsuspecting construction guys who come in for a quick bite and run back outside afterwards to take a couple of more drags on their cigs. haha.

My mom's also bought a couple of cakes here too -- not too sweet, which is exactly what friends say when they take a bite. (Too much fruit though, in my opinion. I'm not really a fruit girl.) The light cheesecake is really good, too! 

Overall, a solid bakery.
author: Betty T.

description: My all time favorites are shredded dried pork with ham and cheese roll, ham and egg bun, and mango cake (whole cake). All the bake items are pretty good. Egg tart is so so, the tart base is too thick for my liking. I like their buns more than fridge desserts.
author: Y Y.

description:
what i ordered... pork sung bun and egg tart

pork sung bun was very good, kindda like a pork bun but imagine the fillings to be smoothly grounded and a bit salty and dry. egg tart was ok, it looks big like napoleon's but in reality it was half the size in terms of fillings/custard. crust was thick it resembles and tasted like a salty butter cookie.

ambiance...ok(hole in a wall)
service... ok
cost... $-(fair)
author: Gors P.

description:
I really don't see why this place deserves any more than a 3 stars rating at the most. I do understand in comparison to it's neighborhood competitor bakeries, it is much nicer in decor and cleanliness, but it's pastries are really just OK. I've had better Chinese bakeries elsewhere, like Kee Wah. 

The buns were pretty decent so I did buy a hot dog bun and a cocktail bun to try, but be warn...NOT everything is. I learned it the hard way. I was really hungry when I was there, so when my mom offered me to buy me one of their Tiramisu desserts...I fell for it. OMG...it's like the WORSEST Tiramisu I've EVER eaten! Typically, Tiramisu is really light but this was super rich with buttercream! WTF?! I barely tasted any coffee flavor in it, and of course there's no surprise there wasn't any rum in it, plus there really wasn't any sign of sponge cake or ladyfingers in any of the three layers! Uh...do I even needa say more??? It was totally disastrous! THE TIRAMISU SUCKED BIG TIME!!! I really should've known better! Yuck!

Anyhow, there are two things that I did like about this place despite of my bad Tiramisu experience. One is that most of it's its pastries are presented in display cases that ppl can just grab with a pair of thongs and put it onto a tray. It's totally self-serve so ppl can get whatever they desire without pressure...and it does make it more fun and totally HK-style. The other thing was that they are not cheapsakes like other Chinese bakeries, they actually provide BOXES for the pastries, not white or clear plastic grocery bags! I hate it when they put tart-like items in it and it always ends up getting smushed. So, kudos for them for not being cheap! :)

It really comes down to whether if I'll come back here again. I would if it's a convenience to me, but for their buns only though.
author: Winnie L.

description: I hate that they put raisins inside the custard bun. Yuk! But the custard is delicious
author: Nina C.

description: The Egg & Ham Bun was simply amazing! Shockingly cheap for SF food.
author: Ike M.

description:
For my birthday yesterday I got a chocolate mousse cake from this place. It was a true work of art. From the fresh, vibrant fruit on top to the detailed chocolate stars around the edge it was a real masterpiece.

It was also delicious of course, but to be fair, it's hard to mess up chocolate mousse.

I'm diabetic and allow myself to splurge on cake for birthdays only and this one was completely worth it!
author: Brad D.

description:
This place is the BOMB DIGGITY. lol - I can't believe I said that but this place really makes me happy.

They have the most amazing breads.  My boyfriend LOVES LOVE LOVES the one with the pork song on the sides and a little bit of ham and onion encrusted all over with a little bit of mayo in the middle. Yummy.

I loved corn and ham and the onion and ham buns.  And they have the one with the hot dog. OMG. 

Anyways definitely worth checking out. It's oh so delicious!!
author: Zu W.

description:
OMG! A Hong Kong styled bakery right in my neighborhood that's NOT Shengke or Sogo or ABC! Ahh reminiscence of Hong Kong (even though I was born here, I went back nearly every summer) where there's bakeries like this everywhere, even in the subway station.

Let's start by saying that the other "Hong Kong" styled bakeries on San Bruno (there's only 2 others), do not match up to this bakery!

My cousin introduced me to his place today to get a birthday cake for my co-worker. A great choice it was. I got the $18 cake, relatively cheap imo, and it was really good! My co-worker loved it! It wasn't super sweet or too sweet, it was just right and fluffy.  They also gave us a party pack that included forks, plates, candles, and a cake cutter. How cool is that? I don't think any other bakeries provide those extras free with purchase. Oh! We also got a free apron with our order!

As I was waiting in the bakery with my cousin, we drooled at all the yummy goodies they offered, believe me it was a lot! Thanks to Wilhelm, I get to stare at them and drool right now too on the pictures. I'm definitely hitting this place up again tomorrow to try their other goodies. The place is very clean, the pastries are very attractive, so attractive that I'm still drooling right now thinking about it! 

Definitely go give this place a try!

BTW... I convinced the BF to drive by this place tonight as well, it was open well past 7pm!
author: Natalie G.

description: YUMMY!  This bakery is delicious!  I love the cakes, I love the pastries, I love the mooncakes -- everything I've gotten here was so yummy.  Whenever I go back to San Francisco and there is any reason to have cake -- I will definitely buy it from this bakery!  It is an amazing find.  :-)
author: Carrey W.

description:
Employees were really rude, and their buns are quite chewy! 
the pineapple bun was not good at all!
author: sherry h.

description: I have to say, I'm loving this place. I love the different types of bread they offer. I recently tried the Milk bread, oh my, it really does remind me of milk. My favorite is the cheese ham roll. It's so fattening but it's soooooo good. Also, try the cheese/garlic bread if they still make it. I really liked that one too. Everything is awesome. Pricy, but awesome.
author: Vicky P.

description: If possible I would have give this place a negative star! People are extremely rude especially the cashier. I bought a slice of cake couple days ago and was gonna bring it home for my kid. The cake was collapsed on the plate cuz it's not firm enough.  I asked the cashier for a to go box, she refused to give and was COMMANDING me to eat the cake right away in the store due to the cake was collapsed and she was unable to put it into a PAPER BAG. I wonder how could they put a slice of cake into a PAPER BAG if I would like to keep its original shape?!? The cashier gave me a warning saying she will not give me a box next time while I insist to bring the cake home.....OMG....She thought I will return? HELL NO!!
author: Jessica C.

description: Discovered this place when walking on San Bruno Ave. Their BBQ bun tasted alright . Their hot dog bun was just so-so . Their dinner roll tasted okay but it lacked flavor ... it was neither sweet or salty . Their lemon jelly bread tasted alright . The bread was not bad but the lemon jelly just tasted okay . I didn't expect them to use lemon jelly though ... I expected them to use lemon curd or something like that . It probably would've tasted better if they used lemon curd instead . Lastly , their milk bread was amazing ... it was ight , fluffy , and delicious . They have an nice , interesting selection of breads , buns , and pastries here . I will definitely be back to try more !
author: Eileen L.

description:
Thanks to Wilhelm I found out about this HK place. YUMmers and don't have to step through C-town's crazy Ahmas and Babaz to get in for the goood HK style desserts.

It just seems so removed from most of the places I like to peruse, but it certainly works for getting something before heading down the Peninsula for the gathering!!!!
author: miriam b.

description:
Great bakery!! kinda chaotic because there really isn't a line like other Chinese bakeries.  I've tried the big coffee cake mango cake and they were both really good.  The cakes have fresh fruit and aren't too sweet.  The buns are good too.  I like the hotdog bun, ham and egg, corn bun, and green onion ham bun.  It's super cheap too.  I don't know how they make a profit.

Pros: cheap for very good quality baked goods.

Cons: chaotic scream for attention service.
author: Amy C.

description: Considered pricey compared to other Chinese bakeries but one thing always makes me come back here anyway: their egg custard tarts. @.@!!!!
author: Louise N.

description:
Great little Gem on San Bruno Ave. I tried their, Pork Sung Cake(semi-circular), Custard Bun, and Light Angel Cheese Cake. All very good. I esp. like the Pork Sung Cake. The bakery is a Pork Sung heaven. They have Pork Sung in quite of few items. 
Nice Atmosphere. Well lit and clean. Not much seating. But worth the trip there, if I ever pass by.
author: Toeknee T.

description: The short chinese girl who works the cashier threw the receipt at me.  Disrespectful, because she knows that I'm not Chinese,
author: James C.

description: A good Hong Kong style bakery. They sell Chinese and European baked goods. The prices are super low and the selections are great. The place is very clean and well lit.  I liked several of their items. Especially the chocolate mousse and their light cheesecake. Their creamy milk cake and pork buns are very good. However, a couple of the items they sell taste a little bland. This is a self service bakery. You pick any item and put it on the tray and bring it to the counter.  I been there several times and it is the most apealing and inviting of the Chinese bakeries on San Bruno Avenue.
author: Hiroshi K.

description:
Started going to this place this past summer and have returned at least twice every week for my morning bun to go with my morning paper.

I've had their ham&egg, cheese&garlic, coconut, custard, black sesame, macau egg tart, fruit tart, corn&cheese, and green onion&cheese bun. All but the black sesame are yums, and I would definitely recommend the ham&egg and cheese&garlic buns. The black sesame is a little bland, they could have added more black sesame paste.

The ladies behind the counter are so nice-there have been times when I didn't bring in enough money, and I would need to run out to the car to get more, and they didn't make me wait in line again when I returned.  Definitely great customer service.
author: Liz C.

description: I like this place, it's always packed when I'm there. The buns are good and it's pretty cheap. The desserts are good too.
author: Liping H.

description: I've lived in this neighborhood 7 years and never seen this place. Everything looks yummy. It's like a having a Sheng Kee bakery right near by. Very awesome. I just wish they had portuguese egg tarts. I'd be in heaven.
author: Gessa C.

description: This bakery is great. Tasty fresh baked items for cheap.
author: Ben K.

description: Parent used to be a regular at this bakery, they have this self service going on. Price is decent, good selection of Baos. However they always tend to run out fast, and they dont restock fast. I would either come out empty handed, or with something not fresh. I would definately come here for the cakes though.
author: Jared Z.

description: Amazing bread here. I always get the pineapple buns, and my boyfriend gets the one with the hot dogs. It's the best chinese bakery in SF, and pretty clean too. Cash only, most things are between $ 0.50 to $2 so you don't a lot. Only bad thing is they run out of some of their breads sometimes because everyone in the neighborhood stops by this place.
author: Aundria G.

description:
Oh man I can't believe this place exists in Portola sometimes. The place is small, but they crank out some serious eatery for lack of a better word. In the morning, it can get pretty busy with people coming in-and-out, and not just Chinese people.

They have everything you could possibly want in a Chinese bakery, the birthday/wedding cakes, the everyday chashao bao for your morning breakfast. Oh and everything is so well-designed about this place, the packaging for everything is so professional.

I am a big fan of the boluo bao (pineapple buns).
author: David L.

description: We were actually on our way to Mona Lisa Restaurant on Columbus when we passed the bakery (that is another review). It smelled so good when we passed by the door that I had to stop. I pulled my wife and daughter in with me and we were greeted with a cheerful hello. We took a while looking around the shop picking out numerous items from the oatmeal cookies made with sesame to the honey loaf bread. The staff was friendly and helpful in answering our questions about the products. Everything that we purchased was absolutely wonderful and fresh. We all enjoyed the pastries as they are so flavorful without being sweet. I am just disappointed that we live 400 miles. I have to contact them to see if they will ship their product. Other reviews have complained about parking and poor customer service. Parking: It's San Francisco! As indicated above, the customer service was just fine as we were treated well.
author: Robert G.

description:
hmmm.. idk y this place comes up twice on yelp,. but ok. 

anyway. gooooooood pastries. cheap. cant go wrong. they also have some reallllly cute cakes... (stuff i've never seen like mango covered mango cake? and its pretty good too) the strawberry mousse was amazingggggg... (only thing is, they only had it once when i went there)

another thing that sucks is the language barrier, but ur able to just grab and pay so thats always a plus. NO words exchanged! lol
author: Lisa N.

description: My former student lives in this neighborhood, while taking her home today I followed her to this bakery (we both were craving pineapple buns). This is the first kind of bakery I've seen where it's actually modeled after bakeries in Hong Kong and Taipei which made me a feel a bit nostalgic for both cities. They have a wide selection of buns, bread, and cakes.  I'm very picky about pineapple buns and I loved it! I live quite a bit far from here but I would come back just to get another pineapple bun!
author: selina n.

description: this place may serve VERY VERY VERY GOOD PASTRIES AND CAKES but THE CUSTOMER SERVICE REALLY SUCKS! i always come here to buy birthday cakes because they make them VERY well but when it comes to check out and picking up your cake, they look at you like you're not worth buying the cake! when selecting pastries, if you're not picking anything up quick then you better not pick it up at all. a sells rep would eventually come to you and accuse you of touching all the pastries! the glares and the stares that these employees send out are downright rude and unpleasant. if it wasn't for their delicious pastries, i would rate this place one star!
author: Crystal L.

description: I only gave three stars because the cashiers customer service was very bad. I will reconsider to do business with these people again.
author: Ken L.

description: I can not find a menu list on this website pls help!!!!!
author: Ed W.

description:
everything looks beautiful

there buying bread is a bit weird, I have to pick up a tray and get by myself???wtf
author: Derrick S.

description:
This place has some great quality stuff!  I love their coconut bread.  So light, fluffy and sweet.

Glad to see that many others like this place.
author: Victoria L.

description: I love this bakery everything is fresh, tasty, beautiful packaging and great prices.
author: Fatima S.

description: i love this place! finally an asian bakery that bakes their bread and baked goods with love:) they are made fresh, its not something expensive, but if you compare it to other  bakeries that sell the same thing it is, my favorite is the bread with cheese, ham, and chives and pork sung is super good! this is breakfast to asian people, and also dim sum too! its something for everyone though! and the employees here wear such cute aprons and what not. theyre super nice too!
author: Jessica C.

description: It's hard for me not to give FWF five stars... This place is becoming a regular morning stop on my way to work. I love to have my taste buds teased, and fancy a good mouth watering followed up by inspiring combinations of deliciousness. FWF does all that and more with the baked goods alone. Yesterday I tried the pineapple bun, today I indulged in a custard filled bun (with a few exciting raisins); this place is already claiming a spot in my "addicted to" tray. I can't wait to hit up the desserts that have been crafrted with high artistry (or so they seem). I'm a fan of eye popping presentations and extra yum yumm yumminess. Pls don't let me down... See you tmw fwf?  *wink, wink*
author: jamranhar h.

description:
This small hole in the wall has a surprising selection of wonderful deliciousness that I have never seen anywhere else. But I was conservative in trying the new things in the two times I have been there. Of the four simple things I tried, the worm shape bread is the most memorable and comforting.  It is just a bun filled with cream, which other places have and I normally would not get. But this thing is insanely good, with light cream in a cloud-fluffy bun and just the right amount of sweetness to let you to eat the whole thing without filling sick to your stomach. It almost melts in your mouth when eaten warm. And this thing has some sort of magical powers. On my first bite, I felt like I was somewhere else for a split second, and melted all my troubles away. Am I describing drugs? Well, I do recommend it to drug addicts who are trying to quit! :-)

The second thing I tried was the green onion bun with dry pork crumble. Again, not entirely original unlike the other things I haven't tried. And I like  this from other places too.  But this thing has intense flavors, with no different layering whatsoever - everything just blows up in your mouth. Salty from the dry pork crumble and green onion, savory from the mayo/cream in the middle, and light sweet from the bun. Combining with the same super fluffiness as the worm shape bun, this almost took me on a trip again.

I normally would not praise so highly of baked buns, but these are definitely some of the best things I ever ate.  And I can't wait to go back to try the different things.
author: Samantha C.

description: To pop my yelp cherry, I decided to review Fancy Wheat Field Bakery.  And I can't think of any other place to be my "first".  Try their "hot dog buns".  They are only 90 cents, and they have the perfect balance of fluffy, slightly sweet bread with a cute, tasty hot dog.  My favorite is the pineapple bun, and at only 50 cents, it's possibly the best bargain in San Francisco.  They have a wide selection of buns, and also, cakes/desserts at very cheap prices.  And the ladies wear the most adorable aprons!  If you aren't asian though, be prepared to be stared at the old asian guys that hang out in the limited seating inside the store.  Oh, cash only, but at these prices, you could probably dig through your pockets and find enough to buy yourself something to eat.
author: Albert S.

description:
After reading all these great reviews about this bakery, I decided to check them out. Besides, I have a wedding coming up in May, so I was also checking out different bakeries and looking at their wedding cakes. 

I got to the store and was not greeted. But that's okay. I went to the counter and asked the lady that I wanted to look at their wedding cake pictures and samples. She then handed me a photo album. I flipped through it and saw only about 5-6 different styles of wedding cakes. Not too impressive, but of the pictures that they had, they looked really pretty. I then went to the lady (at the counter) and asked for more information. I asked for the price and she did not know how much so she went to the back and asked the "bakery chef". She then came back out with the price of $625. I then asked how much I needed to place the order in advance. She again said she didn't know, and then proceeded to head to the back again and asked the chef. She came back out with the answer one more time. So I asked her how much deposit I need to make and by when will I have to make the deposit by. She AGAIN said she didn't know and AGAIN proceeded to the back and asked again. She again came back out with the answer. HOW RUDE! First of all, it's fine that the front counter ladies KNEW NOTHING at all, but to run back and forth just wasn't very professional. And I bet the "bakery chef" who had all the answers (price, deposit, and other info, etc. ) is the BOSS, or at the very least, a manager of the bakery. If that's the case, why isn't my business good enough for him/her to come out and greet me? It wasn't very nice to have a customer stand around and have a counter lady (who knew nothing!) run back THREE TIMES to get some very very basic answers. I felt unappreciated so I picked up my order and left the store. 

I also order a chestnut birthday cake and it is not as good as the reviews rave. They were too sweet and the cake wasn't very spongy / soft at all. So if you want rude service and overpriced cake, by all means, this is the place for you. Otherwise, I would recommend Sunset Bakery on 9th and Judah.
author: Debby W.

description:
similar mock bakery of Sheng Kee

they have individually packaged pastries and not packaged ones...noms...i always get the ham + egg bun. SUPER CHEAP & GOOD & FULFILLING (better than some places in SF CHINATOWN & you dont have to go the distance or stress about parking)

Breakfast for less than $1. what can you ask for...

oh yeah, they're super busy in the mornings...so if you walk in and there's none on display - you should go up to the register and ask for it =] they're really friendly!
author: Steph L.

description:
I was walking to Johnson's and noticed a brand new bakery. It looked really clean, so I took two dollars and decided to try two things. I got the pineapple bun and the pork sung roll (i think that's what it's called). I went back into the car and devoured it within minutes. It was so good! I went back in there and bought more pastries. 

I normally go to Sheng Kee but I actually think this place is better. The cakes are really cute and their mousses looks delicious. It's a great place to buy some pastries for visiting parents. I liked how they have clean trays and tongs for customers to use. It does remind me of Hong Kong bakeries. It's really small, just like Hong Kong. 

I think I'll try the cake there next time. But for now, I have a ton of pastries to eat! I recommend this place!
author: bob k.

description: This is one of the best hk bakeries in the Bay Area as good as the bakeries in HK.    The place is actually owned by a HK corporation based in Kowloon with stores in China too.  Location sucks and wish they have a store in MIllbrae.
author: Jackie T.

description: I must really like this place since I go out of my way to buy their Chinese style bread pastries almost every morning. And yeah it's affordable. I spend less than $2 everytime and that fills me up, not an easy feat if you ask anyone who knows me. I also bought a mango mousse cake here once and people ate it all up. Definitely one of the best Chinese bakeries in the Bay Area.
author: Jason J.

description:
My mom and I stopped by yesterday to get my dad a birthday cake since we were in the area. The shop is clean and organized. The pastries look good, especially the tiny cheesecakes inside the refrigerator. We ended up getting the mango cake, the one with slices of mango fully wrapped around the cake. The cake was $24, which was $1 more than the green tea mousse cake and the Tiramisu cake. The fruits on the outside looked and tasted really fresh. However, the mango was a bit sour. The filling was also filled with pieces of mango instead of the standard fruit mix. I believe they used 2 types of mangoes in the cake. It would be better for them to use the Ataulfo mango for the entire cake because they tend to be sweeter, instead of just having bits of them in the filling. But I guess the Ataulfo is a bit smaller in size and they wouldn't be able to cover up the cake. Aside from the sourness, the texture of the cake is not smooth. They did not do a good job in preparing the cake mixture and you can see little holes in the cake layer. 

Sheng kee is still the better choice for me. They are better at cake making at the very least. Don't let the appearance fool ya.
author: Cris C.

description: Finally... a good chinese bakery on San Bruno Avenue.  I love the mango mousse cake, strawberry mousse cups and bbq pork buns.  Lunch for less than $3.00, you can't beat that.
author: Cookie S.

description: I love all their baked goods! Starting with their pork sung buns and cheese garlic bread, the walnut tarts, honeycomb cakes, and red bean filled buns, yummy! So glad they opened this on San Bruno Ave!
author: Rennie Z.

description: I LOVE this place. The cakes are great. You gotta try the mango cake and the strawberry mango mousse cake. I also love the sesame cookies and the ham pork sung rolls ain't too bad either. I'm actually thinking of picking up a cake there tomorrow for my uncle's birthday. shhh....don't tell nobody. ;-)
author: Leanne M.

description: I love the things inside of the fridge. Delicious, yes. ive only tasted about 4 things from that fridge, all of them good. the mango cake, yumm. The strawberry mango mousse cup, goodness. They used to put real strawberry ice cream inside the mousse cups, but now they're gone. The chocolate and orange mousse with cake in the middle is very good. then comes the custard, yummy. I love the packaging. I'm a sucker for cute cups and small spoons. i don't really like their savory non-fridge things. too dry. I also dont like how they dont have a selection of drinks in a fridge. they only have coffee and milk tea(?)
author: Danielle Y.

description: I have been to this place a couple of times since its near my house. I like the bbq pork buns because it has a hint of sesame seed oil. Also they use fried eggs in their  ham and egg buns. I wish they have chicken pie or beef curry puff.
author: Carl W.
